communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Confined Disposal Facility Application
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I would like to request a copy of the following documents:

A. The application submitted by the Corps to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency on March 19, 2021, regarding the renewal and modification of the Water Pollution Control Permit No. 2016-EO-60898, pertaining to the Corps’ operation of the existing Confined Disposal Facility ("CDF"). 

B. The request submitted to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency on March 1, 2023, for certification under Section 401 of the Clean Water Act related to its proposed vertical expansion of the Confined Disposal Facility.

C. The letter received by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers sent from the Illinois Environmental Protection agency on April 6, 2023, which requested additional information to the former request. 

D. The letter detailing the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers' withdrawal of its request, sent to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency on January 24, 2024. 

I have attached to this request a letter from the IEPA Acting Director sent to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, which details the existence of these documents (second page, first paragraph).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Britton Struthers-Lugo

communications.subject: FOIA Request Returned - FA-25-0022
communications.communication:
Activity Control Number:  FA-25-0022

Dear Ms. Struthers-Lugo,

I am writing in response to your request under the Freedom of Information Act to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Chicago District, received January 27, 2025.

You requested:

(1) "All emails, inclusive of attachments, between the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency relating to the "Calumet Dredged Material Disposal Facility" ("DMDF") and the "Confined Disposal Facility" ("CDF") from July 11, 2024 through present";

(2) "The application submitted by the Corps to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency on March 19, 2021, regarding the renewal and modification of the Water Pollution Control Permit No. 2016-EO-60898, pertaining to the Corps' operation of the existing Confined Disposal Facility ("CDF");"

(3) "The request submitted to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency on March 1, 2023, for certification under Section 401 of the Clean Water Act related to its proposed vertical expansion of the Confined Disposal Facility;"

(4) "The letter received by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers sent from the Illinois Environmental Protection agency on April 6, 2023, which requested additional information to the former request;" and

(5) "The letter detailing the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers' withdrawal of its request, sent to the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency on January 24, 2024."

All responsive records that our agency possesses pertaining to this request are being provided to you via DoD Safe. You should receive a separate email from DoD Safe with instructions on how to access your records.

Any redactions that were applied to the response records are explained in the attached letter.

Under the FOIA, we are required to charge for the direct cost of processing your request. But because the cost of processing your FOIA request was nominal, no fees will be assessed.

I trust that this information fully satisfies your request. If you need any further assistance or would like to discuss any aspect of your request, please do not hesitate to contact me or our FOIA Public Liaison at foia-liaison@usace.army.mil<mailto:foia-liaison@usace.army.mil>.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Very Respectfully,

Jenna McCreary
Paralegal Specialist
U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Chicago District
231 S. LaSalle Street, Suite 1500
Chicago, IL 60604
Office:  312.846.5332
Cell:  312.504.9883

communications.subject: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. All email correspondence, with attachments, mentioning "Water Property Investors," "Water Property Investor II," or "Water Property Investor III." 

2. Pitch decks, prospectuses, or any other materials provided to NMERB by the the above funds for consideration of potential investments.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Julia Rock

communications.subject: Fw: [EXTERNAL] New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Records Requestor:


Your request for information from the New Mexico Educational Retirement Board was forwarded to me. In accordance with the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act (IPRA), “a written request shall provide the name, address and telephone number of the person seeking access to the records and shall identify the records sought with reasonable particularity.” Section 14-2-8(C) NMSA 1978.


If you will provide me with your name and mailing address, we can begin the process of allowing inspection of the relevant records.


The Inspection of Public Records Act can be found at 14-2-1 through 14-2-12 NMSA 1978.


Thank you.


Amanda Olsen



Amanda Olsen, Paralegal
NM Educational Retirement Board
PO Box 26129
Santa Fe, New Mexico 87502
(505) 476 6133
(505) 827-8030 fax

My mailing address is 4521 N Central Park Ave. 3W, Chicago IL 60625. My phone number is 781-962-8816. Please feel free to give me a call if it's helpful to discuss any portion of this request. 

Thank you!

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Scroggins and Ms. Olsen,

Thanks for the update. Can you provide any additional info regarding the source of delays on this request, or the estimated delivery date? Please feel free to give me a call at 781-962-8816 if it'd be helpful to discuss the scope of the materials we're requesting.

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock,

I am responding to your email yesterday requesting any additional info regarding the source of delays on this request. Please be assured that we make every effort to respond promptly to every request. However, we must also ensure that we are diligent and accurate in our reply. Thus, when obtained, all documents and emails must be reviewed. Additionally, we must rely on the state agency that controls the entire state email system to identify and provide the emails requested. As you can imagine, the process takes time.

As to an estimated response date, in our letter of August 1, 2023, we noted that we intend to respond by September 6, 2023.

Thank you for your patience and please feel free to contact me if you have further questions.

Respectfully,

[cid:image001.png@01D9C623.0D3F7D80]

communications.communication:
Hello Ms. Garcia,

Thank you for the update. Given that it's now been five months since we filed the initial request, are you able to provide an update as to whether you've identified the responsive documents, or what the source of the delay is?

Thank you,

Rebecca

communications.subject: ATTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGED - RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns,

Thank you for your inquiry and please accept our apologies for the delay.

As Mr. Scroggins noted in his August 3, 2023 email regarding our projected response, we always try to be prompt.  But as you might guess, the request references a large number of records.  As he said, we must thoroughly review all records to identify and obtain the responsive documents from both external and internal sources.  It is a complex and time-consuming process.

I am confident that we will have documents ready to provide on or before the December 6th, 2023, date noted in our recent communication.

Thank you for your continued patience!
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image002.png@01DA121F.C2136CB0]

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hi,

Thanks so much for your help with this request! I really appreciate it.

Sincerely,
Julia Rock

communications.subject: Re: Request for Inspection of Records
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns:

As discussed in our letter of December 6, 2023, we are providing the records we currently have available in response to your June 16, 2023, request.  They are located at the website below:

MuckRock - Julia Rock<https://nmgov-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/r/personal/renee_garcia_erb_nm_gov/Documents/MuckRock%20-%20Julia%20Rock?csf=1&web=1&e=4gwfSH>

As also discussed, we will require additional time to provide the remainder of the records.  We plan to provide additional documents on or before February 1, 2024.  Thank you again for your continued patience regarding this matter.
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image001.png@01DA29F0.5D899B00]

files.title: image001
files.source: New Mexico Educational Retirement Board, New Mexico

files.title: WAM-000001NMERB
files.source: Melinda

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hello Renee,

Thank you for your continued partnership on this request. Please know that we are unable to access the SharePoint link you had provided. Our email address is not showing as associated with the link: 147140-15493170@requests.muckrock.com.

Please advise at your earliest convenience.

Thank You,

MuckRock Staff

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hello Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns,

We apologize for the error you received while trying to access the records. We will be using another method for delivery. Attached are the instructions that you will need to connect to the ERB SFTP server.  I will send you the credentials in a secure email to follow this.

As also discussed, we will require additional time to provide the remainder of the records. We plan to provide additional documents on or before February 1, 2024. Thank you again for your continued patience regarding this matter.
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image001.png@01DA2C20.B2CBD790]

communications.subject: Your one-time passcode to view the message
communications.communication:
Here is your one-time passcode 00961754 
To view your message, enter the code in the web page where you requested it. 
NOTE: This one-time passcode expires 15 minutes after it was requested. 
This message is automatically generated. Please don't reply to it.

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Thank you so much for your assistance, Renee. I was able to download the documents via the server instructions you provided. I look forward to your response on or before February 1st for the remaining documents.

Have a wonderful holiday season!

communications.subject: Re: Request for Inspection of Records
communications.communication:

Attached is additional correspondence regarding your June 16, 2023 request.

Thank you,


[Jennifer Jaques  Paralegal/Legal Assistant  Jennifer.Jacques@erb.nm.gov]

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (January 2025) (Pierce County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

title: Marin PD RIPA requests (Belvedere Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Marin PD RIPA requests (Belvedere Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1) Any and all records reflecting data collected and recorded by the Police Department in accordance with the California Racial and Identity Profiling Act (RIPA) from January 1, 2022, through the present. Please provide the raw data in excel or csv format.

2) Any and all reports, records, and analyses created by, for, or at the direction of, the City/Town that pertain to any RIPA data that has been collected by the Police Department since January 1, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Frank Shinneman

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Marin PD RIPA requests (Belvedere Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following California Public Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Jan. 15, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: City of Belvedere: Public Records Act Request
communications.communication:
Dear Frank Shinneman,


In response to your Public Records Act Request received on January 15, 2025, please find attached RIPA data documents from January 2022 through present. These documents are a component of the Belvedere Police Chief's quarterly reports to City Council.



Thank you,

Beth Haener

City Clerk

City of Belvedere

450 San Rafael Avenue

Belvedere, CA 94920-2336

tel 415.435.8913


PUBLIC DISCLOSURE NOTICE:

This email and any attached files were sent from an email account assigned to a public official for the City of Belvedere.  This email, replies to this email, or emails sent directly to this email account may constitute a public record and, if retained during the normal course of business, may be subject to disclosure to any person upon request.

files.title: RIPA DATA Jan 2022- Dec 2024
files.source: Belvedere Police Department, Belvedere, CA

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Marin PD RIPA requests (Belvedere Police Department)
communications.communication:
Beth Haener,

Thank you for the summary of the monthly RIPA presentations made to your council.  This is NOT responsive to my request. As your Chief Wu knows, the Office of the Attorney General of the State of California requires regular reporting of RIPA as proscribed by the RIPA Board. This full data has is being reported to the state by all other Marin police departments and the Sheriff's Office and has been provided for the requested period in response to an identical request.

Therefore, I repeat my original Public Records Request, to wit I request the following in the format provided to the RIPA board whether formatted by the City of Belvedere or any vendor to the Town.

Best Regards,
Frank Shinneman

1) Any and all records reflecting data collected and recorded by the Police Department in accordance with the California Racial and Identity Profiling Act (RIPA) from January 1, 2022, through the present. Please provide the raw data in excel or csv format.

2) Any and all reports, records, and analyses created by, for, or at the direction of, the City/Town that pertain to any RIPA data that has been collected by the Police Department since January 1, 2022.

communications.subject: Re: California Public Records Act Request: Marin PD RIPA requests (Belvedere Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Shinneman,

Attached is an excel spreadsheet that is responsive to your request.

Please note that the City of Belvedere does not typically have possession of this information in this format. In this unusual circumstance, we have a record that is responsive to your request – but in the future, it is very unlikely that the City would be in possession of similar documents for a different timeframe.



Thank you,

Beth Haener

City Clerk

City of Belvedere

450 San Rafael Avenue

Belvedere, CA 94920-2336

tel 415.435.8913


PUBLIC DISCLOSURE NOTICE:

This email and any attached files were sent from an email account assigned to a public official for the City of Belvedere.  This email, replies to this email, or emails sent directly to this email account may constitute a public record and, if retained during the normal course of business, may be subject to disclosure to any person upon request.

Sincerely,

Kelly North

title: FOIA Request for Case-Related Materials - Joseph Gerdvil

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: FOIA Request for Case-Related Materials - Joseph Gerdvil
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am writing to formally request access to public records under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). Specifically, I am requesting any and all records and materials related to the case of

Suspect Name: Joseph Gerdvil
Description/Headline: US Man, Who Beheaded Parents, Sings To Cops As They Shoot At Him
Link of the Article: https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/us-man-sings-to-cops-as-they-shoot-him-after-he-chopped-off-parents-heads-6419623
State: Los Angeles CA
Law Enforcement: Orange County California Sheriff's office

included but not limited to the following:
Documents:
Incident reports
Investigation reports
Officer statements
Witness statements
Any other relevant case files

Footage:
Body camera footage from officers on the scene
Dash camera footage
Police surveillance camera footage
Private/public surveillance footage from nearby locations
Any footage collected as evidence or during the investigation

Audio:
911 calls
Police radio communications
Any other audio recordings related to the case
Visual Media:
Crime scene photographs
Surveillance stills
Photographs taken during the investigation

Court Records:
Transcripts from court hearings or proceedings
Any video/audio footage from court hearings
Court orders or any other court-related documents

Please include any and all materials, regardless of format (digital or physical), including those not listed above that are related to the case in question.
Additionally, if this request has been sent to the wrong department or agency, I would appreciate it if you could provide guidance or contact information for the correct department or agency that handles such requests.

If any part of the request is denied or redacted, please provide a detailed explanation of the specific legal exemption that applies.
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response within the period mandated by FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

david yupa

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

david yupa

ATTN: Orange County Sheriff’s Department

320 N. Flower Street
Santa Ana, CA 92703

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, describing or generated as a part or result of the cancelation of events scheduled for Thursday, March 12, 2020: National Declassification Center: Reflecting on our Beginnings, Forecasting our Future and the Multi-Agency Forum: Using FOIA to Access Intelligence Community Records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma Best

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (February 2025) (Garfield County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (February 2025) (Garfield County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Natural Disaster Nutrition Assistance Expenditure
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1.	Expenditures for any provision of nutritional assistance to individuals and households, including but not limited to bottled water, prepared food, or packaged food products for the years 2000-2024. Expenditures may include direct provision, contracted provision, or provision via another entity such as contribution to an interagency effort.
2.	Expenditures on the Disaster Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, provisioned annually or by FEMA Disaster Number.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Johanna Rayl

Sincerely,

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Natural Disaster Nutrition Assistance Expenditure
communications.communication:
Dear FNS FOIA Office,

Thank you so much for the data provided. I have two questions to help me understand the records.

1. Could you elaborate on the column 3 title, "Number of LBS", on Sheet 2 of the record? What does LBS stand for and what does the column contain?
2. Does the total expense reflect both direct provision of food as well as expenditures on coupons/vouchers/cash for households to make their own food purchases? If so, is it possible to see a breakdown across these two categories, or would it require another FOIA request?

Thank you very much,
Johanna

communications.subject: RE: [External Email]RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Natural Disaster Nutrition Assistance Expenditure
communications.communication:
Please see the response below regarding the 2 questions that you asked:

1.          LBS is the abbreviation for pounds and the column contains pounds of food distributed.
2.          The value provided is only for food distributed.  There is no cash issued for households to purchase their own foods.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Former governor J. Joseph Garrahy
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records, specifically those unreleased, mentioning or describing John Joseph Garrahy, known to many as J. Joseph Garrahy, who was the former governor of Rhode Island. He was born on Nov. 26, 1930 and died Jan. 24, 2012. (Obituary: https://www.dignitymemorial.com/obituaries/providence-ri/j-garrahy-10574589)

I've submitted this request to the FBI, and the agency said records responsive to my request were transferred to NARA. Some may be in file number 157-HQ-8428 serial 430.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexa Gagosz

Dear Alexa Gagosz:

I am writing in response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request
of November 21, 2024 for records in the custody of the National Archives
and Records Administration. Your request was received in this office on
November 25, 2024 and assigned FOIA tracking number RD 88010.

You requested access to FBI file 157-HQ-8428 Serial 430 on John Joseph
Garrahy AKA J. Joseph Garrahy. My initial assessment is that John Joseph
Garrahy AKA J. Joseph Garrahy is the subject of the records, compiled as
part of a Civil Unrest investigation, created between March 15, 1968 and
March 19, 1968, and consisting of an estimated 12 pages.

These records require review for information protected from release under
the FOIA: https://www.archives.gov/foia/foia-guide#determine. This will be
assigned to a staff member as the next case they work on.

You must notify this office of changes to your contact information. If
communication is returned as undeliverable and no return address is

information or to track the status of your request, please email
specialaccess_foia@nara.gov or call 301-837-3190. Please include your FOIA
tracking number in all communications concerning this request.

If you are not satisfied with our action on this request and would like the
opportunity to discuss our response, you may contact our FOIA Public

communications.subject: FOIA Request RD 88010
communications.communication:
Dear Alexa Gagosz:

I am writing in response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request
of November 21, 2024 for records in the custody of the National Archives
and Records Administration. Your request was received in this office on
November 25, 2024 and assigned FOIA tracking number 8810.

You requested access to FBI file 157-HQ-8428 Serial 430 on John Joseph
Garrahy AKA J. Joseph Garrahy. My initial assessment is that John Joseph
Garrahy AKA J. Joseph Garrahy is the subject of the records, compiled as
part of a Civil Unrest investigation, created between March 15, 1968 and
March 19, 1968, and consisting of an estimated 12 pages.

I completed a line-by-line review of the records you requested. Please be
advised, we have considered the foreseeable harm standard when reviewing
records and applying FOIA exemptions for this request. Information was
released to the greatest extent possible. Below is a summary of our review:

Records Requested

Total Pages

Pages Released in Full

Pages Released in Part

Pages Withheld in Full

157-HQ-8428 Serial 430

12

11

1

0


I withheld information protected under section (b) of the FOIA (5 U.S.C.
552). The specific reasons for the denials are:

TYPE OF INFORMATION WITHHELD

FOIA EXEMPTION

identities of confidential sources

(b)(7)(D)

Attached is a complimentary reproduction of the records for your use.

If you are not satisfied with my action on this request, you have the right
to file an administrative appeal within ninety (90) calendar days from the
date of this letter. Appeals must be in writing and may be delivered by
regular U.S. mail or by email. By filing an appeal, you preserve your
rights under the Freedom of Information Act and present the deciding agency
with an opportunity to review your request and reconsider its decision. If
you submit your appeal by regular mail, it should be addressed to the
Deputy Archivist of the United States (ND), National Archives and Records
Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road, Room 4200, College Park, Maryland
20740-6001. Both the letter and envelope should be clearly marked “FOIA
Appeal.” If you submit your appeal by email, please send it to foia@nara.gov,
addressed to the Deputy Archivist, with the words “FOIA Appeal” in the
subject line. If you exercise your right to appeal, please explain why you
believe this response does not meet the requirements of the Freedom of
Information Act. All communications concerning this request should
reference your FOIA tracking number.

If you would like the opportunity to discuss my response and attempt to
resolve your dispute without initiating the appeals process, you may
contact our FOIA Public Liaison for assistance:

Accessioned Executive Branch Records – Washington, DC Area

FOIA Requester Service Center: 301-837-3190

title: Exposing Systemic Failures in Medicaid Oversight, ADA Enforcement, and Whistleblower Protections to Ensure Justice and Transparency for All Americans (National Archives and Records Administration)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Exposing Systemic Failures in Medicaid Oversight, ADA Enforcement, and Whistleblower Protections to Ensure Justice and Transparency for All Americans (National Archives and Records Administration)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Freedom of Information Act Request
Date: November 23, 2024
Submitted By: David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources
39 Kings Hwy STE C
Gales Ferry, CT 06335

Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request – Records Pertaining to Transparency, ADA Compliance, Whistleblower Protections, Medicaid, and Related Matters

To:
Freedom of Information Act Officer
U.S. Department of Justice
Office of Information Policy (OIP)
441 G Street NW, Sixth Floor
Washington, DC 20530-0001

CC:
Kristen Clarke, Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights Division
Bobak Talebian, Director, Office of Information Policy
Aundra Luckey, Freedom of Information/Privacy Acts Unit, Civil Rights Division
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS), National Archives and Records Administration
Relevant Congressional Oversight Committees

Introduction
Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, I request access to all records, communications, and agreements from the Department of Justice (DOJ) and related agencies. This request is submitted under federal law to ensure transparency, constitutional compliance, and accountability concerning whistleblower protections, ADA enforcement, and Medicaid oversight. The requested information holds significant public interest in safeguarding civil rights, promoting systemic reform, and ensuring taxpayer accountability.

Scope of Request
1. Case Identifiers
Provide all records and inter-agency communications related to the following cases:
539330-JBZ, 539298-RJM, 534659-XGL, 534094-QZH, 534069-BRQ, 534060-HWM, 533252-GXC, 535276-FSL, 532832-MJV, 532674-QMM, 532671-PPV, 532667-DRF, 523966-VSF, 497211-PFB, 490797-TJJ, 489456-MCB, 490814-TPF, 490215-DKH, 478957-DPX, 478956-NSD, 473045-JNW, 452335-DDT, 413343-FZP, 405540-ZXW, 397760-PRZ, 395050-TWW, 392179-NCW, 385105-BPN, 376153-JVL, 357494-WND, 354718-LTZ, 275528-PKR, 301882-TRG, 327008-WFC, 339860-FQG, 352533-WJH.

2. ADA Compliance and Enforcement
Records, communications, and agreements related to:

ADA Title II enforcement policies.
Complaints or investigations regarding ADA non-compliance in Medicaid programs.
Inter-agency communications between DOJ, CMS, and other entities concerning ADA accommodations, including whistleblower protections.
3. Whistleblower Protections

All records, policies, and communications involving whistleblower protections under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).
Internal policies addressing retaliation protections for individuals reporting non-compliance with FOIA, ADA, or Medicaid oversight.
4. Medicaid Oversight

Internal audits, investigations, and compliance reviews conducted by the DOJ, CMS, and other agencies.
Records of Medicaid provider complaints, sanctions, or violations under the Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program.
Communication regarding systemic Medicaid transparency failures.
5. Processing Records

Metadata, logs, and records detailing how this FOIA request has been processed, including internal communications, software platforms used, and timestamps for all actions.
6. Cross-Referenced Searches
Ensure a thorough search of:

Digital archives, email servers, and shared inter-agency platforms.
Archived repositories, including records stored by supervisory personnel and contractors.
Constitutional and Statutory Justifications
First Amendment

Access to information is critical for public participation in governance, as recognized in New York Times Co. v. United States (1971).
Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments

Procedural delays and denials violate due process and equal protection under the law (Tennessee v. Lane, 2004).
Supremacy Clause (Article VI, Clause 2)

Federal FOIA and ADA laws supersede any conflicting agency-specific practices.
Relevant Statutes and Case Law

FOIA: 5 U.S.C. § 552, U.S. DOJ v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press (1989).
ADA: Title II, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794.
Whistleblower Protections: 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).
Non-Negotiable ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility, I request adherence to the following accommodations:

MuckRock Platform Only: All communication must occur via MuckRock. Phone calls, external portals, and physical mail are prohibited.
Text in Email Body: Embed all response text in the email body for screen-reader compatibility.
Screen-Reader Compatible PDFs: All documents must be clearly labeled and provided in accessible formats.
Simplified Summaries: Include clear summaries for complex records.
Identification of Personnel: Provide names, titles, and contact information of all responsible individuals.
Statutory Justifications: Include detailed explanations for any redactions or denials, citing specific FOIA exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b).
Expedited Processing: As this request involves public interest and ADA rights, process expeditiously under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E).
Public Interest Framing
This request directly serves public interest by:

Ensuring transparency and accountability in government programs involving taxpayer funds.
Safeguarding constitutional rights under the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments.
Highlighting systemic reform needs in ADA enforcement, Medicaid transparency, and whistleblower protections.
Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with this request will result in:

Judicial Action: Pursuing legal remedies for injunctive relief and damages under FOIA and ADA statutes.
Oversight Escalation: Filing complaints with DOJ OIG, OGIS, or federal courts.
Public Disclosure: Engaging media, advocacy groups, and watchdog organizations to expose systemic non-compliance.
Conclusion
This request invokes the highest standards of constitutional law and statutory obligations. I expect a complete and transparent response within 20 business days, as required under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A).

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

CC:
Kristen Clarke (Assistant Attorney General)
Bobak Talebian (Director, Office of Information Policy)
Aundra Luckey (FOIA/PA Unit, Civil Rights Division)
OGIS (Office of Government Information Services)
Merrick B. Garland (Attorney General)
Chiquita Brooks-LaSure (CMS Administrator)
Xavier Becerra (HHS Secretary)
Congressional Oversight Committees:

House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
House Subcommittee on Civil Rights and Civil Liberties
Senate Judiciary Committee Chairperson
Additional Oversight Entities:
U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO)
Office of Special Counsel (OSC)
House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

Chairman: James Comer (R-KY)
Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

Chairman: Gary Peters (D-MI)
House Subcommittee on Civil Rights and Civil Liberties

Chairman: Jamie Raskin (D-MD)
Senate Judiciary Committee

Chairman: Dick Durbin (D-IL)
Additional Oversight Entities:

U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO)

Comptroller General: Gene L. Dodaro
U.S. Office of Special Counsel (OSC)

FOIA compliance, ADA accommodations, Medicaid transparency, systemic reform, whistleblower protections, accountability in government, healthcare fraud investigations, Medicaid oversight, DOJ records request, civil rights enforcement, accessibility advocacy, whistleblower retaliation, constitutional law, First Amendment transparency, Fifth Amendment due process, Fourteenth Amendment equal protection, taxpayer accountability, inter-agency communications, OIG audits, congressional oversight, GAO reviews, federal-state coordination, Medicaid fraud prevention, healthcare policy reform, government transparency. FOIA Exemption Codes (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)):   b(1), b(3), b(5)) Whistleblower Protections (5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8)): "ADA compliance," "Title II violations," and "civil rights complaints" DOJ, CMS, FBI, OIG, OSC, GAO, DHS Medicaid fraud," "systemic discrimination," "government transparency," and "FOIA litigation DB.42.131.Inf. Statutory and Executive Codes
5 U.S.C. § 552: Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) – Mandates transparency and inter-agency cooperation for information sharing.
42 U.S.C. § 12132: Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Title II – Requires accessibility and cross-agency compliance.
29 U.S.C. § 794: Rehabilitation Act, Section 504 – Prohibits discrimination across federally funded programs.
5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8): Whistleblower Protection Act – Shields employees reporting violations across agencies.
Executive Order 13392: Improving Agency Disclosure – Calls for government-wide improvements in FOIA processing.
44 U.S.C. § 3501: Paperwork Reduction Act – Encourages streamlined data sharing and reduced duplication.
31 U.S.C. §§ 3729-3733: False Claims Act – Promotes inter-agency coordination in addressing fraud and misuse of federal funds.
6 U.S.C. § 485: Homeland Security Information Sharing – Establishes cross-agency information-sharing protocols. "Systemic enforcement challenges requiring cross-agency collaboration."
"Mandated by Executive Order 13392 for improved inter-agency transparency."
"Coordinated federal response necessary for compliance with 42 U.S.C. § 12132."
"In alignment with Unified Federal Response Framework principles."
"Urgent action required to address inter-agency statutory obligations under FOIA and ADA." Office of Management and Budget (OMB): Coordinates federal budget and compliance.
Government Accountability Office (GAO): Investigates federal agency operations.
Office of Special Counsel (OSC): Manages whistleblower disclosures.
Department of Justice (DOJ) Civil Rights Division: Enforces ADA and civil rights laws.




This Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request demands the immediate attention of the highest authorities in the U.S. government. It directly addresses systemic failures in Medicaid oversight, ADA enforcement, and whistleblower protections—issues central to the lives of millions of Americans and critical to the integrity of federal and state programs. By exposing potential misuse of taxpayer funds and barriers to accessibility for vulnerable populations, this request transcends individual cases to reveal a broader narrative of systemic accountability, justice, and public trust. Leaders in Congress, the Department of Justice, and oversight agencies have a constitutional obligation to act decisively on this matter to uphold the values of transparency, equality, and justice that underpin our democracy. Failure to respond promptly and fully to this FOIA request risks exposing entrenched inequities that erode public faith in our institutions.

This FOIA request also represents a rallying cry for journalists, advocates, and every American committed to justice and systemic reform. It shines a spotlight on the intersection of healthcare, civil rights, and government accountability, demanding immediate national discourse and united action. As the most comprehensive and consequential transparency effort in U.S. history, it calls for investigative reporting that transcends political divisions and highlights the universal human rights at stake. This is not just a request for information—it is a demand for transformative change, and its response has the potential to shape the future of U.S. healthcare and governance, sparking a nationwide movement for accountability, equity, and justice.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

DAVID MEDEIROS

communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Medeiros:

Thank you for submitting your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to
the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) via email to
foia@nara.gov.  We received your request on December 3, 2024.  Your request
states:

*I request access to all records, communications, and agreements from the
Department of Justice (DOJ) and related agencies. This request is submitted
under federal law to ensure transparency, constitutional compliance, and
accountability concerning whistleblower protections, ADA enforcement, and
Medicaid oversight. The requested information holds significant public
interest in safeguarding civil rights, promoting systemic reform, and
ensuring taxpayer accountability.*
*Scope of Request*
*1. Case Identifiers **Provide all records and inter-agency communications
related to the following cases:*
*539330-JBZ, 539298-RJM, 534659-XGL, 534094-QZH, 534069-BRQ, 534060-HWM,
533252-GXC, 535276-FSL, 532832-MJV, 532674-QMM, 532671-PPV, 532667-DRF,
523966-VSF, 497211-PFB, 490797-TJJ, 489456-MCB, 490814-TPF, 490215-DKH,
478957-DPX, 478956-NSD, 473045-JNW, 452335-DDT, 413343-FZP, 405540-ZXW,
397760-PRZ, 395050-TWW, 392179-NCW, 385105-BPN, 376153-JVL, 357494-WND,
354718-LTZ, 275528-PKR, 301882-TRG, 327008-WFC, 339860-FQG, 352533-WJH.*
*2. ADA Compliance and Enforcement **Records, communications, and
agreements related to: **ADA Title II enforcement policies. **Complaints or
investigations regarding ADA non-compliance in Medicaid programs.
**Inter-agency
communications between DOJ, CMS, and other entities concerning ADA
accommodations, including whistleblower protections.*
*3. Whistleblower Protections **All records, policies, and communications
involving whistleblower protections under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8). **Internal
policies addressing retaliation protections for individuals reporting
non-compliance with FOIA, ADA, or Medicaid oversight. *
*4. Medicaid Oversight **Internal audits, investigations, and compliance
reviews conducted by the DOJ, CMS, and other agencies. **Records of
Medicaid provider complaints, sanctions, or violations under the Acquired
Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. **Communication regarding systemic
Medicaid transparency failures.*
*5. Processing Records **Metadata, logs, and records detailing how this
FOIA request has been processed, including internal communications,
software platforms used, and timestamps for all actions.*
*6. Cross-Referenced Searches **Ensure a thorough search of: ...*

Our office handles FOIA and Privacy Act requests for NARA’s operational records
(records created by this agency).  Because your FOIA request is for records
that may be archival records (records created by or originated in a
different agency but that may have been transferred to the legal custody of
NARA), we are forwarding it by this email to our Office of Research
Services, Textual Reference (RR2RR) staff who handle FOIA requests for
textual archival records.

That office will assign your request a tracking number and respond directly
to you. In the future, if you need to follow up with that office directly,
please contact them at the address below, or electronically via email
(email is preferred).

National Archives and Records Administration
Research Services, Textual Reference Branch (RR2RR)
8601 Adelphi Road, Room 2400
College Park, MD 20740

Phone: 301-837-3091
Fax: 301-837-1752
Email: archives2reference@nara.gov

For your reference, a copy of your request is below.

Please visit our website at www.archives.gov/foia for further information
about making a FOIA request to NARA.  On our main website,
www.archives.gov, you
can learn more about the resources we offer to the public, and you can
access our online catalog.

Sincerely,

<https://www.archives.gov/>

  Ashley Bryan

  Government Information Specialist

  Operational FOIA and Access Division

  College Park, Maryland, 20740-6001

  301-837-3642

   <https://www.archives.gov/foia>   <foia@nara.gov>
<https://www.archives.gov/foia/contacts>
<https://www.archives.gov/foia/electronic-reading-room>
<https://www.archives.gov/ogis/resources>

Freedom of Information Act Request

Founder, ABI Resources
39 Kings Hwy STE C
Gales Ferry, CT 06335

Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request – Records Pertaining to Transparency,

Introduction
Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, I

Department of Justice (DOJ) and related agencies. This request is submitted
under federal law to ensure transparency, constitutional compliance, and
accountability concerning whistleblower protections, ADA enforcement, and
Medicaid oversight. The requested information holds significant public
interest in safeguarding civil rights, promoting systemic reform, and
ensuring taxpayer accountability.

Scope of Request

following cases:
539330-JBZ, 539298-RJM, 534659-XGL, 534094-QZH, 534069-BRQ, 534060-HWM,
533252-GXC, 535276-FSL, 532832-MJV, 532674-QMM, 532671-PPV, 532667-DRF,

Records, communications, and agreements related to:

ADA Title II enforcement policies.
Complaints or investigations regarding ADA non-compliance in Medicaid
programs.
Inter-agency communications between DOJ, CMS, and other entities concerning
ADA accommodations, including whistleblower protections.
3. Whistleblower Protections

All records, policies, and communications involving whistleblower
protections under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).
Internal policies addressing retaliation protections for individuals
reporting non-compliance with FOIA, ADA, or Medicaid oversight.
4. Medicaid Oversight

Internal audits, investigations, and compliance reviews conducted by the
DOJ, CMS, and other agencies.
Records of Medicaid provider complaints, sanctions, or violations under the
Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program.
Communication regarding systemic Medicaid transparency failures.
5. Processing Records

Metadata, logs, and records detailing how this FOIA request has been
processed, including internal communications, software platforms used, and
timestamps for all actions.
6. Cross-Referenced Searches
Ensure a thorough search of:

Digital archives, email servers, and shared inter-agency platforms.
Archived repositories, including records stored by supervisory personnel
and contractors.
Constitutional and Statutory Justifications
First Amendment

Access to information is critical for public participation in governance,
as recognized in New York Times Co. v. United States (1971).
Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments

Procedural delays and denials violate due process and equal protection
under the law (Tennessee v. Lane, 2004).
Supremacy Clause (Article VI, Clause 2)

Federal FOIA and ADA laws supersede any conflicting agency-specific
practices.
Relevant Statutes and Case Law

FOIA: 5 U.S.C. § 552, U.S. DOJ v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the
Press (1989).
ADA: Title II, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation
Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794.
Whistleblower Protections: 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).
Non-Negotiable ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility, I request adherence to the following
accommodations:

MuckRock Platform Only: All communication must occur via MuckRock. Phone
calls, external portals, and physical mail are prohibited.
Text in Email Body: Embed all response text in the email body for
screen-reader compatibility.
Screen-Reader Compatible PDFs: All documents must be clearly labeled and
provided in accessible formats.
Simplified Summaries: Include clear summaries for complex records.
Identification of Personnel: Provide names, titles, and contact information
of all responsible individuals.
Statutory Justifications: Include detailed explanations for any redactions
or denials, citing specific FOIA exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b).
Expedited Processing: As this request involves public interest and ADA
rights, process expeditiously under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E).
Public Interest Framing
This request directly serves public interest by:

Ensuring transparency and accountability in government programs involving
taxpayer funds.
Safeguarding constitutional rights under the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth
Amendments.
Highlighting systemic reform needs in ADA enforcement, Medicaid
transparency, and whistleblower protections.
Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with this request will result in:

Judicial Action: Pursuing legal remedies for injunctive relief and damages
under FOIA and ADA statutes.
Oversight Escalation: Filing complaints with DOJ OIG, OGIS, or federal
courts.
Public Disclosure: Engaging media, advocacy groups, and watchdog
organizations to expose systemic non-compliance.
Conclusion
This request invokes the highest standards of constitutional law and
statutory obligations. I expect a complete and transparent response within
20 business days, as required under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A).

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

CC:
Kristen Clarke (Assistant Attorney General)
Bobak Talebian (Director, Office of Information Policy)
Aundra Luckey (FOIA/PA Unit, Civil Rights Division)
OGIS (Office of Government Information Services)
Merrick B. Garland (Attorney General)
Chiquita Brooks-LaSure (CMS Administrator)
Xavier Becerra (HHS Secretary)
Congressional Oversight Committees:

House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

communications.subject: Re: [25-14028] Freedom of Information Act Request - David Medeiros
communications.communication:
Dear David Medeiros,

This is in reply to your Freedom of Information Act request, dated December
3, 2024 for various records related to ADA Title II compliance and
enforcement, whistleblower protections, and Medicaid oversight. Your
request was received in this office on December 12, 2024 and assigned the
case number 25-14028.

In reviewing your request, we have determined that your request for
expedited processing does not meet the threshold outlined in NARA's FOIA
regulations, specifically 36 CFR 1250.28. However, since we were able to
complete your FOIA within the 20 days allotted by the law, your request for
expedited processing is moot.

Please see below our response to each item of your request:



*1. Case IdentifiersProvide all records and inter-agency communications
related to the following cases:539330-JBZ, 539298-RJM, 534659-XGL,
534094-QZH, 534069-BRQ, 534060-HWM, 533252-GXC, 535276-FSL, 532832-MJV,
532674-QMM, 532671-PPV, 532667-DRF, 523966-VSF, 497211-PFB, 490797-TJJ,
489456-MCB, 490814-TPF, 490215-DKH, 478957-DPX, 478956-NSD, 473045-JNW,
452335-DDT, 413343-FZP, 405540-ZXW, 397760-PRZ, 395050-TWW, 392179-NCW,
385105-BPN, 376153-JVL, 357494-WND, 354718-LTZ, 275528-PKR, 301882-TRG,
327008-WFC, 339860-FQG, 352533-WJH.*

We conducted a search in the National Archives Catalog
<https://catalog.archives.gov/advanced-search> with these case file numbers
and did not locate any records responsive to your request. Please note that
the file numbers you provided do not match the typical format of Department
of Justice case files. Generally, Department of Justice case files are
designated by a case file number with a three-part numerical file
designation, such as 144-15-2301.

If you believe these files originated with a federal agency other than the
Department of Justice, please let us know.


*2. ADA Compliance and EnforcementRecords, communications, and agreements
related to: *

*ADA Title II enforcement policies. *
*Complaints or investigations regarding ADA non-compliance in Medicaid
programs. *
*Inter-agency communications between DOJ, CMS, and other entities
concerning ADA accommodations, including whistleblower protections.*

Department of Justice ADA Title II enforcement files are held in Class 204
(State and Local Governments Under the Americans with Disabilities Act
[Title II]) Litigation Case Files and Enclosures, 1991–2003
<https://catalog.archives.gov/id/7430863> (Entries A1-COR 204 and A1-ENC
204) in *Record Group 60: General Records of the Department of Justice*. This
series consists of litigation case files and enclosures relating to
allegations by individuals that, by reason of their disability, they were
either excluded from participation in or denied the benefits of the
services, programs, or activities of state and local governments or were
subjected to discrimination by state and local governments, which are
illegal under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990.

These records are arranged by Department of Justice case file number. We do
not hold any name indexes to the records. In order to locate records
related to specific cases of interest to you, you would first need to
submit a FOIA request to the Department of Justice Civil Rights Division
<https://www.justice.gov/crt/freedom-information-act-0> requesting that
they provide you with the case file numbers (also referred to as "DJ
numbers") for the individuals or organizations that interest you.

Department of Justice case file series also often include a set of policy
and procedure files, filed under the file designation -012. Policy and
procedure files for Class 204 (ADA Title II) case files would therefore be
filed under the designation 204-012. We conducted a search and did not
locate any records in our holdings filed under file designation 204-012. We
suggest submitting a FOIA request to the Department of Justice Civil Rights
Division, as they may still retain those records.

We also conducted a search in the National Archives Catalog for ADA Title
II files in the records of Department of Justice senior officials. Most DOJ
senior leadership records that have "Title II" in the file title actually
relate to Title II of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. However, we did locate
the following 3 files that are responsive to your request:

Record Group 60
Subject Files of the Special Assistants to the Assistant Attorney General
Entry P 266
Box 138
Files: Title II Letters; Enforcing the ADA - Status Reports

Box 139
Files: Enforcing the ADA - Status Reports

These records are subject to access restrictions and need to be reviewed
for categories of information exempted from disclosure under the Freedom of
Information Act (FOIA). We are transferring this portion of your request to
our Special Access and FOIA staff for further action. The Special Access
and FOIA staff will be in contact about the status of your request.



*3. Whistleblower ProtectionsAll records, policies, and communications
involving whistleblower protections under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).Internal
policies addressing retaliation protections for individuals reporting
non-compliance with FOIA, ADA, or Medicaid oversight.*
We searched the National Archives Catalog in *Record Group 60: General
Records of the Department of Justice *and identified several files
responsive to your request.

The following file is open and available for research:

Record Group 60
Subject Files of the Special Assistants to the Assistant Attorney General,
1974–2000
Entry A1 1091
Box 366
File: [Thornburgh, Richard] ACTS Whistleblower Protection of 1989 (1989)

We would be happy to make the above file available to you in our research
room or to provide you with reproductions. You can find information about
visiting NARA or ordering reproductions at the end of this response.

The following records are subject to access restrictions and need to be
reviewed for categories of information exempted from disclosure under the
Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). We are transferring this portion of your
request to our Special Access and FOIA staff for further action. The
Special Access and FOIA staff will be in contact about the status of your
request regarding these records:

Record Group 60
Subject Files of the Special Assistants to the Assistant Attorney General,
1974–2000
Entry A1 1091
Box 477
File: [Thornburgh, Richard] Legislation Whistleblower Closed (1989)

Subject Files of the Deputy Assistant Attorney General, 1982–1993
Entry P 272
Box 261
File: [Bryan, Patricia M.] Whistleblower Case

Subject Files of the Associate Deputy Attorney General, 1969–1994
Entry P 190
Box 164
File: [Howard, John L.] Legislation - Whistleblower Protection Act

Box 179
Files: [Howard, John L.] Whistleblower Protection Act 1; [Howard, John L.]
Whistleblower Protection Act 2



*4. Medicaid OversightInternal audits, investigations, and compliance
reviews conducted by the DOJ, CMS, and other agencies.Records of Medicaid
provider complaints, sanctions, or violations under the Acquired Brain
Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. Communication regarding systemic Medicaid
transparency failures.*
We searched the National Archives Catalog in *Record Group 60: General
Records of the Department of Justice* and *Record Group 440: Records of the
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services *and identified the following
files and series as responsive to your request.

Record Group 60
Subject Files of Assistants to the Attorney General, 1974–1994
Entry P 71
Box 364
File: [Cynkar, Robert J.] Medicaid Fraud Control Unites

This file is open and available for research. We would be happy to make the
above file available to you in our research room or to provide you with
reproductions.

Record Group 60
Files of Associate Deputy Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, April 1,
1994–April 30, 1997
Entry UD-13W 20
Box 2
File: CRIM/Florida Medicaid <https://catalog.archives.gov/id/44132173>

This file has been digitized and is available to access at the link above.

Record Group 440
Inspector General Audit Correspondence, October 1, 1988–September 30, 2005
Entry UD-23W 15

This series consists of correspondence, memorandums, and draft reports on
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services matters under audit by the
Department of Health and Human Services, Office of Inspector General. The
series consists of approximately 24 cubic feet (~55,000 pages) of records
and is open and available for research. We would be happy to make these
available to you in our research room or to provide reproductions of
specific files of interest to you. Attached is a box and folder list for
the series.

*5. Processing Records and 6. Cross-Referenced Searches*
*Metadata, logs, and records detailing how this FOIA request has been
processed, including internal communications, software platforms used, and
timestamps for all actions.*
These are active operational records that NARA creates in carrying out its
mission and responsibilities as an executive branch agency, rather than
archival records. NARA's General Counsel Office provides responses for FOIA
requests for operational records. We have referred this portion of your
request to them and they will provide you with a separate response.

*Visiting NARA and Ordering Reproductions*

We would be happy to make the open records available to you in the Textual
Research Room at the National Archives at College Park, MD. Please visit
our website for information about visiting the National Archives at College
Park <https://www.archives.gov/college-park>, including how to schedule a
research visit. Scheduling an appointment in advance is encouraged but not
required.

All researchers must register for a researcher card. Please complete the online
researcher orientation
<https://rise.articulate.com/share/uK5NGkSpg74JHLTOcGPmM4e94MJyxQgD#/> as
well as the online researcher registration form
<https://researchercommunity.force.com/securitycentral/s/kiosk-registration>
before
scheduling an appointment.


We can also offer reproductions of specific open files of interest to you.
Reproductions are $0.80 per page with a minimum fee of $20.00. If there are
specific files you wish to order scans of, please let us know and provide
your preferred billing address.


You will be able to receive digital copies of the documents if you choose.
You are under no obligation to purchase reproductions after receiving a
price quote. Our policy is to process reproduction orders for files in
batches of three. Each batch takes approximately 30-60 days to process. We
will work on the next batch after payment and delivery of copies/scans has
been made for the prior batch.

We do not consider this a denial of your FOIA request. However, if you are
not satisfied with our action on this request, your options for appeal and
dispute resolution are outlined in the attachment. If you have any
questions, you may reach us at archives2reference@nara.gov.

This completes the processing of your request.

Sincerely,

David Castillo
Archives Specialist
Textual Reference Archives II Branch (RR2RR)
National Archives at College Park, MD

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #25-14028
communications.communication:
Escalated Complaint and FOIA Appeal

Date: December 23, 2024

Formal Escalated FOIA Appeal and Complaint Regarding Systemic Non-Compliance, Violations of Constitutional Rights, Whistleblower Protections, Taxpayer Rights, and ADA Obligations

To: All including
David Castillo, Archives Specialist, NARA
Kristen Clarke, Assistant Attorney General, DOJ Civil Rights Division
Bobak Talebian, Director, DOJ Office of Information Policy

CC:
Merrick Garland, U.S. Attorney General
Xavier Becerra, Secretary, HHS
Chiquita Brooks-LaSure, CMS Administrator
Relevant Congressional Oversight Committees

Subject:
Formal Escalated FOIA Appeal and Complaint Regarding Systemic Non-Compliance, Violations of Constitutional Rights, Whistleblower Protections, Taxpayer Rights, and ADA Obligations

*** Attached to this complaint is a comprehensive document detailing a systemic failure across multiple federal and state agencies to uphold constitutional rights, enforce statutory protections, and ensure government accountability. The document includes:

Specific Case Records and Identifiers: Highlighting critical instances of oversight failures, ADA non-compliance, whistleblower retaliation, and Medicaid program mismanagement.
Legal Analysis and Violations: A thorough examination of constitutional, FOIA, ADA, whistleblower, and taxpayer law violations, supported by relevant statutes and case law.
Unfulfilled Records Requests: Evidence of procedural deficiencies, incomplete searches, unjustified denials, and improper referrals in response to lawful FOIA requests.
Demands for Relief and Accountability: A clear outline of the required corrective actions, including full disclosure of records, ADA-compliant accommodations, and expedited resolution.
Framework for Oversight: Steps for immediate escalation to Congressional committees, judicial remedies, and oversight bodies if compliance is not achieved.
This submission presents irrefutable evidence and a legally robust argument demonstrating how the failure to act jeopardizes public trust, violates federal laws, and undermines the foundational principles of transparency, accountability, and justice. The attached document is not merely a request for compliance—it is a demand for systemic reform and adherence to the rule of law.
Introduction

This is a formal escalated complaint and FOIA appeal regarding systemic failures and procedural violations in responding to my FOIA request dated November 23, 2024. This request sought essential records related to Medicaid oversight, ADA enforcement, whistleblower protections, and systemic accountability, as outlined in federal law.

To date, responses have been inadequate, failing to meet statutory and constitutional standards. This appeal invokes the highest legal protections to demand immediate corrective action under FOIA, the U.S. Constitution, whistleblower statutes, taxpayer rights, and the ADA.

1. Constitutional Rights Violations
Violations:

First Amendment:

Denial of access to critical records obstructs my right to petition the government for redress of grievances.
Case law: New York Times Co. v. United States, 403 U.S. 713 (1971).
Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments:

Procedural delays and denials constitute a deprivation of due process and equal protection under the law.
Case law: Goldberg v. Kelly, 397 U.S. 254 (1970).
Actions Demanded:

Immediate compliance with FOIA to ensure due process and transparency in matters affecting constitutional rights.
Full disclosure of interagency communications, audits, and investigative records tied to Medicaid oversight and ADA enforcement.
2. Whistleblower Protections
Violations:

Failure to produce records relating to whistleblower disclosures and retaliatory actions undermines protections under 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8).
Suppression of investigative findings erodes federal safeguards intended to protect individuals exposing systemic failures.
Case law: Lane v. Franks, 573 U.S. 228 (2014).
Actions Demanded:

Full disclosure of whistleblower-related policies, protections, and communications.
Immediate release of all withheld or redacted documents with a Vaughn Index citing exemptions and foreseeable harm standards.
3. Taxpayer Rights Violations
Violations:

Lack of transparency in Medicaid program oversight breaches obligations under the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act and related statutes.
Denial of requested records hinders public accountability for taxpayer funds allocated to the ABI Waiver Program.
Case law: United States v. Klein, 80 U.S. 128 (1871).
Actions Demanded:

Disclosure of all internal audits, investigations, and compliance reviews involving Medicaid fraud, provider violations, and ABI Waiver Program oversight.
Oversight accountability to ensure federal funds are not misused or misallocated.
4. ADA Compliance Failures
Violations:

Ignoring explicit accommodation requests under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).
Failure to provide screen-reader-compatible documents, plain-language summaries, or accessible communication formats.
Case law: Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004).
Actions Demanded:

Immediate provision of all records in accessible formats, including screen-reader-compatible PDFs and plain-language summaries.
Confirmation of compliance with all ADA accommodation requirements for this and future requests.
Deficiencies in Agency Responses
1. Case Identifiers:
No meaningful search was conducted for requested records. Agencies failed to engage in interagency coordination or conduct cross-referenced searches as required by 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3).

2. Whistleblower Protections:
Agencies failed to provide responsive documents and offered no Vaughn Index or legal justification for redactions.

3. Medicaid Oversight:
NARA acknowledged records exist but imposed unreasonable logistical and financial barriers, ignoring accommodation requests.

4. ADA Accommodations:
Despite explicit requests, agencies failed to provide accessible formats or simplified summaries.

Demands for Immediate Relief
1. Comprehensive FOIA Compliance:

Conduct a thorough search for all requested records across NARA, DOJ, CMS, and other relevant agencies.
Provide all responsive documents without unjustified redactions, supported by a Vaughn Index.
2. ADA-Compliant Accommodations:

Deliver all records in accessible formats, including screen-reader-compatible PDFs.
Include plain-language summaries for technical or legal documents.
3. Accountability and Oversight:

Assign a single point of contact responsible for ensuring interagency compliance with FOIA, ADA, and whistleblower statutes.
Submit unresolved issues to the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) for mediation.
4. Expedited Processing:

Approve expedited processing under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E), given the compelling public interest in this matter.
Deadline for Compliance
A full and compliant response must be provided by December 30, 2024. Continued non-compliance will result in:

Filing formal complaints with OGIS and the DOJ Inspector General.
Escalation to Congressional Oversight Committees.
Pursuing judicial remedies under FOIA, ADA, and constitutional laws.
Conclusion
The systemic failures outlined here undermine public trust and violate federal law. Immediate corrective action is necessary to uphold transparency, accountability, and the rule of law.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources
