communications.subject: NARA Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Request RD 88136
communications.communication:
Dear David Medeiros,

I am writing in response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request
of December 3, 2024 for records in the custody of the National Archives and
Records Administration. Your request was received in this office on
December 26, 2024 and assigned FOIA tracking number RD 88136.

Your initial request was referred to NARA’s Textual Reference with the case
number 25-14028. David Castillo identified the following files as
potentially responsive and required review for information protected under
the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA):


   -

   [Howard, John L] Legislation-Whistleblower Protection Act: Box 164; 1
   folder; May 1988, October 1988; estimated 9 pages



   -

   [Howard, John L] Legislation-Whistleblower Protection Act 1 and
Whistleblower
   Protection Act 2: Box 179; 2 folders; 1987; estimated 300 pages total



   -

   [Thornburg, Richard] Legislation Whistleblower Closed (1989): Box 477; 1
   folder; February - August 1989; estimated 35 pages



   -

   Title II Letters, Box 138; 1 folder; 4 pages



   -

   Enforcing the ADA - Status Report: Boxes 138, 139; April 1994 -December
   1999; 19 folders, estimated 210 pages. “The Enforcing the ADA-Status
   Reports” are also accessible online, https://archive.ada.gov/statrpt.htm.



   -

   [Bryan, Patricia M.] Whistleblower Case: Box 261; 1 folder; May - June
   1990; estimated 75 pages


There are no restrictions on access; these files are open and available for
research.


You or your designated representative may view the files at the National
Archives at College Park, Maryland. We require at least one week advance
notice to prepare for your visit and ask that you email
specialaccess_foia@nara.gov with your FOIA tracking number (RD 88136) and
the date you plan to visit. Please also let us know if you would like us to
book an appointment on your behalf. Please monitor our web page
https://www.archives.gov/college-park for details and updates, as the
operating status for the facility could change, affecting opening hours for
the research rooms.

If you are unable to visit and you wish to hire a researcher to duplicate
the file, information on how to hire a researcher can be found at this
link: https://www.archives.gov/research/hire-help. The National Archives
does not endorse anyone who appears on the list.  It is possible the fees
to hire a researcher may be less than the reproduction fees.

If you cannot visit our College Park facility, you may order a digital or
paper reproduction copy of the file(s) at the cost of 80 cents per page. To
place a reproduction order, please contact our office at
specialaccess_foia@nara.gov or 301-837-3190. A mailing/billing address is
required to generate a price quote, so please include that information with
your reproduction request.

If you are not satisfied with my action on this request, you have the right
to file an administrative appeal within ninety (90) calendar days from the
date of this letter. Appeals must be in writing and may be delivered by
regular U.S. mail or by email. By filing an appeal, you preserve your
rights under the Freedom of Information Act and present the deciding agency
with an opportunity to review your request and reconsider its decision. If
you submit your appeal by regular mail, it should be addressed to the
Deputy Archivist of the United States (ND), National Archives and Records
Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road, Room 4200, College Park, Maryland
20740-6001. Both the letter and envelope should be clearly marked “FOIA
Appeal.” If you submit your appeal by email, please send it to foia@nara.gov,
addressed to the Deputy Archivist, with the words “FOIA Appeal” in the
subject line. If you exercise your right to appeal, please explain why you
believe this response does not meet the requirements of the Freedom of
Information Act. All communications concerning this request should
reference your FOIA tracking number.

If you would like the opportunity to discuss my response and attempt to
resolve your dispute without initiating the appeals process, you may
contact our FOIA Public Liaison for assistance:

Accessioned Executive Branch Records – Washington, DC Area

FOIA Requester Service Center: 301-837-3190

FOIA Public Liaison: Rebecca Calcagno

8601 Adelphi Road, Room 5500

College Park, MD 20740-6001

dc.foia.liaison@nara.gov

301-837-3190

You may also contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS),
the Federal FOIA Ombudsman’s office, for assistance. OGIS offers mediation
services to help resolve disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal
agencies. The contact information for OGIS is:

Office of Government Information Services

National Archives and Records Administration

8601 Adelphi Road–OGIS

College Park, MD 20740-6001

Email: ogis@nara.gov

https://www.archives.gov/ogis

Phone: 202-741-5770 or 1-877-684-6448

This concludes the processing of your request. If you have additional
questions, please contact me directly at purdom.lindblad@nara.gov.

Sincerely,

Purdom
--
Purdom Lindblad
Archivist
Special Access and FOIA Program (RF)
National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road, Room 2350
College Park, MD 20740-6001
purdom.lindblad@nara.gov

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #NGC25-138
communications.communication:
01.16.2025

2. Anonymity and Lack of Accountability in Decision-Making
Unsigned Determination Letters:
Many determination letters from OSC lack identifiable signatures, names, or clear authorship.
This practice raises serious concerns about accountability and compliance with transparency laws.

3. Suppressed or Altered Records
Evidence suggests discrepancies between the whistleblower reports I submitted and how they were recorded or handled by OSC.
Specific issues include:
Alterations or removal of content from submitted complaints.
Suppression of reports that exposed systemic failures in Medicaid oversight and retaliation against whistleblowers.

4. Lack of FOIA Compliance
Despite repeated Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests, OSC and related agencies have failed to provide:
Complete case files and communication logs.
Justification for withheld or redacted information.
Clear timelines for compliance.

Specific Questions to Investigate
1. Who is Responsible for Managing These Records?
Identify the individuals, teams, or automated systems involved in creating, altering, and assigning these case numbers and reports.

2. What Decisions Were Made and Why?
Determine how decisions were reached, why some reports were closed without action, and why letters were sent anonymously.

3. Were There Violations of Federal Law?
Investigate potential obstruction of justice, retaliation, or misuse of authority under whistleblower protection laws and FOIA.

Key Agencies and Officials Involved
This matter spans multiple federal and state agencies, including:
• Office of Special Counsel (OSC)
• Department of Justice (DOJ)
• Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)
• Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
• Office of Inspector General (OIG)

Why This Matters
1. Whistleblower Protections:
Retaliation against whistleblowers and suppression of reports undermine federal protections designed to safeguard transparency and accountability.

2. Impact on Vulnerable Populations:
These failures harm Medicaid consumers, particularly those with disabilities, by allowing systemic mismanagement to persist unchecked.

3. Misuse of Taxpayer Funds:
Lack of oversight and accountability results in waste and misuse of federal funds meant to serve the public.

Requested Actions
1. Investigate Record Management:
Audit all OSC records, emails, and internal communications related to these case numbers.

Identify responsible individuals or systems.
2. Subpoena Additional Evidence:

Secure all suppressed or altered reports to ensure a complete and accurate investigation.
3. Hold Accountable Those Involved in Misconduct:

Recommend prosecution or disciplinary action for any individuals found to have violated federal laws.
4. Ensure Compliance with FOIA and Whistleblower Protections:
Mandate OSC and related agencies to comply fully with FOIA requests and whistleblower laws.

Attachments
I have attached all available documentation, including:
Correspondence with OSC, including determination letters and emails.
FOIA requests and responses (or lack thereof).
Detailed reports submitted to OSC and other federal agencies.

Conclusion
This issue demands immediate attention to uphold the principles of transparency, accountability, and justice. I am available to provide additional information or documentation as needed.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros

As recognized in National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004), transparency is fundamental to democracy and public trust. Your agency’s obligations are not discretionary, and failure to meet them constitutes a violation of statutory and constitutional law. This letter establishes your duties, addresses deficiencies, and anticipates and counters all potential deflection strategies.

1. FOIA Obligations: Statutory Mandates and Required Actions
FOIA establishes an enforceable right of access to federal agency records. Your response must meet the following requirements:

A. Timeliness
Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A), you are required to provide a determination within 20 business days. Delays beyond this timeframe, absent legitimate extension requests, constitute a violation of FOIA.

Countermeasure: Delays are actionable under Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. DOJ, 711 F.3d 180 (D.C. Cir. 2013).
Required Action: Provide the requested records or a lawful determination.

B. Adequacy of Search
FOIA requires a thorough and reasonable search for records, as established in Campbell v. DOJ, 164 F.3d 20 (D.C. Cir. 1998). This includes:

Identifying the databases, locations, and terms used.
Providing a sworn affidavit detailing the search scope.
Countermeasure: A vague claim of "no responsive records" is insufficient without a detailed affidavit.
Required Action: Submit a sworn affidavit documenting the search or confirm the existence of responsive records.

C. Proper Use of Exemptions
Exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b) must be narrowly applied and justified with specific explanations. Blanket or vague exemptions are impermissible.

Countermeasure: A Vaughn index (Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973)) is required to justify each withholding.
Required Action: Submit a Vaughn index detailing each exemption and its justification within 10 business days.

D. Decentralization and Referrals
Referrals or decentralization excuses do not absolve your agency of its responsibility to provide a consolidated response. As held in McGehee v. CIA, 697 F.2d 1095 (D.C. Cir. 1983), agencies must coordinate internally to ensure compliance.

Countermeasure: Require assurance of continuity and coordination across divisions.
Required Action: Consolidate records from all relevant offices and provide a unified response.

2. ADA and Rehabilitation Act Compliance: Equal Access as a Legal Right
As a person with a documented disability, I am entitled to reasonable accommodations under the ADA and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Your failure to provide accessible formats for requested records constitutes discrimination and violates federal law.

Case Law:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004): Agencies must ensure meaningful access to government services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985): Denial of reasonable accommodations creates barriers that violate civil rights.
Required Action:

Provide all requested records in accessible formats, including plain-language summaries or electronic files compatible with assistive technologies.
Confirm compliance with ADA requirements by [specific date].
3. Mandated Reporting and Whistleblower Protections
Your handling of this request implicates broader concerns, including potential fraud, misuse of federal funds, or retaliation against whistleblowers. Under the Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302), you are required to report and address systemic violations.

Countermeasure: Reference Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4), which requires the reporting of observed violations of law.
Required Action: Document and escalate evidence of misconduct to oversight bodies, including the Office of Inspector General (OIG).

4. Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with your statutory obligations knowingly constitutes violations of:

Obstruction of Justice (18 U.S.C. § 1505): Delaying lawful access to records obstructs public accountability.
Civil Rights Violations (42 U.S.C. § 1983): Denying ADA accommodations constitutes a deprivation of federally protected rights.
Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4): Concealing or failing to report observed violations is a criminal act.
Countermeasure: Prepare for judicial review, oversight complaints, and public advocacy if compliance fails.
5. Escalation Pathways
If your office does not comply within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this matter through:

Judicial Review: Filing a lawsuit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel disclosure.
Oversight Complaints: Submitting formal complaints to OGIS, OIG, and the DOJ Civil Rights Division.
Public Advocacy: Engaging investigative journalists, transparency advocates, and public interest organizations to ensure accountability.

6. Final Statement: Upholding Transparency and Accountability
This matter reflects the public’s right to transparency and the preservation of trust in government institutions. Your actions will either affirm your agency’s commitment to accountability or further evidence systemic disregard for these principles.

I look forward to your prompt and substantive response.

David Medeiros

Summary of Responsibilities
Each individual and organization listed plays a crucial role in federal and state oversight, advocacy, and the protection of civil rights. Their functions include but are not limited to:

Oversight & Accountability: Ensuring compliance with federal and state laws, including Medicaid regulations, FOIA, ADA, and civil rights protections.
Transparency & Advocacy: Promoting open government practices and supporting whistleblower activities.
Civil Rights Enforcement: Addressing violations of constitutional and statutory protections against discrimination.
Legislative Oversight: Monitoring government programs and expenditures, particularly those impacting vulnerable populations like Medicaid beneficiaries.
Judicial and Administrative Review: Offering remedies for non-compliance through litigation or administrative actions.

ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.
Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication

All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.
Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.
Identification of Responsible Officers

Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.
Non-Negotiable Compliance

These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

________________________________________________
DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE | OFFICE OF THE INSPECTOR GENERAL January 13, 2025 SENT VIA EMAIL David Medeiros requests@muckrock.com Subject: Freedom of Information/Privacy Act Request [25-OIG-259] Dear David Medeiros: This is in response to your request under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) for access to records maintained by the Office of the Inspector General (OIG). Specifically, you are seeking "OSC Case Records, Complete files, internal and external communications, investigations, and resolutions regarding: DI-25-000310 DI-25-000325 DI-25-000379 DI-12192024714 DI-12112024134," etc. After a thorough search, please be advised that no responsive records were located in the OIG. We consider this response as closing your request with the OIG. For your information, Congress excluded three discrete categories of law enforcement and national security records from the requirements of the FOIA. See 5 U.S.C. § 552 (2012 & Supp. V 2017). This response is limited to those records that are subject to the requirements of the FOIA. This is a standard notification that is given to all our requesters and should not be taken as an indication that excluded records do, or do not, exist. You may contact our FOIA Public Liaison, Deborah Waller, at (202) 616-0646 for any further assistance with your request. Additionally, you may contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at the National Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIA mediation services they offer. The contact information for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 207406001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at (202) 741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. If you are not satisfied with OIG’s determination in response to this request, you may administratively appeal by writing to the Director, Office of Information Policy (OIP), United States Department of Justice, 441 G Street, NW, 6th Floor, Washington, D.C. 20530, or you may submit an appeal through OIP's FOIA STAR portal by creating an account following the instructions on OIP’s website: https://www.justice.gov/oip/submit-and-track-request-or-appeal. Your appeal must be postmarked or electronically transmitted within 90 days of the date of my response to your request. If you submit your appeal by mail, both the letter and the envelope should be clearly marked "Freedom of Information Act Appeal." If possible, please provide a copy of your original request and this response letter with your appeal. 950 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20530-0001 | (202) 616-0646 Sincerely, Marissa Solomon-McRoy Marissa Solomon-McRoy Government Information Specialist Office of General Counsel 2
____________________________________________________

The challenges we face today demand more than acknowledgment—they require action, collaboration, and a unified commitment to solutions. Together, we must embrace transparency, accountability, and compassion as the foundation of our efforts. By fostering open communication, prioritizing the needs of the most vulnerable, and holding systems accountable, we can rebuild trust and ensure equitable outcomes for all.

Solutions lie in unity—when state and federal leaders, advocates, and communities work hand in hand to uphold justice and fairness. Transparency through accessible Freedom of Information processes, adherence to legal mandates, and robust oversight are the pillars that support meaningful change. Each of us has a role to play in creating a system that serves and protects.

Our collective mission is clear: to build bridges between agencies and communities, ensure the dignity of every individual, and honor the principles that guide us toward progress. Together, with determination and unity, we can overcome systemic failures and pave the way for a brighter, more inclusive future.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request NGC25-138
communications.communication:
Sent via Email  <176817-26912251@requests.muckrock.com>


January 23, 2025


David Medeiros
176817-26912251@requests.muckrock.com


RE: Freedom of Information Act Request NGC25-138


Dear Mr. Medeiros,


On December 23, 2024, we received your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)
request that was assigned tracking number NGC25-138.  Your request falls
within one of the “unusual circumstances” categories contemplated by the
FOIA, 5 U.S.C. §552(a)(6)(B)(iii) (I), (II) and (III), and we need
additional time to respond to your request beyond the twenty business days
provided by the FOIA statute. Specifically, we need to search for and
collect potentially responsive records from an office separate from our
office which is processing the request. To enable us to respond more
quickly to you, you may wish to reformulate your request to narrow the
scope of the request or to arrange an alternative time frame for the
processing of this request.

We regret the necessity of this delay but assure you that your request will
be processed as soon as possible.  In accordance with 5 U.S.C.
§552(a)(6)(B)(i) the request will take an additional 10 working days from
the date of this letter.  Please feel free to contact our office if you
have any questions. You may also contact our FOIA Public Liaison, Hannah
Bergman, for assistance at 8601 Adelphi Road, College Park, MD 20740-6002,
301-837-1750, ngc.foia.liaison@nara.gov.

You are also free to seek the assistance of the Office of Government
Information Services (OGIS), the Federal FOIA Ombudsman’s office that
offers mediation services to help resolve disputes between FOIA requesters
and Federal agencies. The contact information for OGIS is noted below:

Office of Government Information Services

National Archives and Records Administration

8601 Adelphi Road–OGIS

College Park, MD 20740-6001

Email: ogis@nara.gov Website: ogis.archives.gov

Tel: 202-741-5770 or 1-877-684-6448


Sincerely,


Operational FOIA Division

National Archives and Records Administration

8601 Adelphi Road

College Park, Maryland, 20740-6001

301-837-3642

*** Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)
Subject: Urgent Request for Investigation into OSC Case Records, Altered Decisions, and Suppressed Reports

Dear FBI Team,

I am formally requesting your assistance to investigate systemic failures, misconduct, and potential criminal activity surrounding the handling of my submissions to the Office of Special Counsel (OSC). These failures directly impact whistleblower protections, Medicaid oversight, and public accountability.

Issues to Investigate

1. Case Numbers and Records Management

2. Anonymity and Lack of Accountability in Decision-Making

Unsigned Determination Letters:

Many determination letters from OSC lack identifiable signatures, names, or clear authorship.

This practice raises serious concerns about accountability and compliance with transparency laws.

3. Suppressed or Altered Records

Evidence suggests discrepancies between the whistleblower reports I submitted and how they were recorded or handled by OSC.

Specific issues include:

Alterations or removal of content from submitted complaints.

Suppression of reports that exposed systemic failures in Medicaid oversight and retaliation against whistleblowers.

4. Lack of FOIA Compliance

Despite repeated Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests, OSC and related agencies have failed to provide:

Complete case files and communication logs.

Justification for withheld or redacted information.

Clear timelines for compliance.

Specific Questions to Investigate

1. Who is Responsible for Managing These Records?

Identify the individuals, teams, or automated systems involved in creating, altering, and assigning these case numbers and reports.

2. What Decisions Were Made and Why?

Determine how decisions were reached, why some reports were closed without action, and why letters were sent anonymously.

3. Were There Violations of Federal Law?

Investigate potential obstruction of justice, retaliation, or misuse of authority under whistleblower protection laws and FOIA.

Key Agencies and Officials Involved

This matter spans multiple federal and state agencies, including:

• Office of Special Counsel (OSC)

• Department of Justice (DOJ)

• Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)

• Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)

• Office of Inspector General (OIG)

Why This Matters

1. Whistleblower Protections:

Retaliation against whistleblowers and suppression of reports undermine federal protections designed to safeguard transparency and accountability.

2. Impact on Vulnerable Populations:

These failures harm Medicaid consumers, particularly those with disabilities, by allowing systemic mismanagement to persist unchecked.

3. Misuse of Taxpayer Funds:

Lack of oversight and accountability results in waste and misuse of federal funds meant to serve the public.

Requested Actions

1. Investigate Record Management:

Audit all OSC records, emails, and internal communications related to these case numbers.

Identify responsible individuals or systems.

2. Subpoena Additional Evidence:

Secure all suppressed or altered reports to ensure a complete and accurate investigation.

3. Hold Accountable Those Involved in Misconduct:

Recommend prosecution or disciplinary action for any individuals found to have violated federal laws.

4. Ensure Compliance with FOIA and Whistleblower Protections:

Mandate OSC and related agencies to comply fully with FOIA requests and whistleblower laws.

Attachments

I have attached all available documentation, including:

Correspondence with OSC, including determination letters and emails.

FOIA requests and responses (or lack thereof).

Detailed reports submitted to OSC and other federal agencies.

This issue demands immediate attention to uphold the principles of transparency, accountability, and justice. I am available to provide additional information or documentation as needed.

As recognized in National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004), transparency is fundamental to democracy and public trust. Your agency’s obligations are not discretionary, and failure to meet them constitutes a violation of statutory and constitutional law. This letter establishes your duties, addresses deficiencies, and anticipates and counters all potential deflection strategies.

1. FOIA Obligations: Statutory Mandates and Required Actions
FOIA establishes an enforceable right of access to federal agency records. Your response must meet the following requirements:

A. Timeliness
Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A), you are required to provide a determination within 20 business days. Delays beyond this timeframe, absent legitimate extension requests, constitute a violation of FOIA.
Countermeasure: Delays are actionable under Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. DOJ, 711 F.3d 180 (D.C. Cir. 2013).
Required Action: Provide the requested records or a lawful determination.

B. Adequacy of Search
FOIA requires a thorough and reasonable search for records, as established in Campbell v. DOJ, 164 F.3d 20 (D.C. Cir. 1998). This includes:
Identifying the databases, locations, and terms used.
Providing a sworn affidavit detailing the search scope.
Countermeasure: A vague claim of "no responsive records" is insufficient without a detailed affidavit.
Required Action: Submit a sworn affidavit documenting the search or confirm the existence of responsive records.

C. Proper Use of Exemptions
Exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b) must be narrowly applied and justified with specific explanations. Blanket or vague exemptions are impermissible.
Countermeasure: A Vaughn index (Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973)) is required to justify each withholding.
Required Action: Submit a Vaughn index detailing each exemption and its justification within 10 business days.

D. Decentralization and Referrals
Referrals or decentralization excuses do not absolve your agency of its responsibility to provide a consolidated response. As held in McGehee v. CIA, 697 F.2d 1095 (D.C. Cir. 1983), agencies must coordinate internally to ensure compliance.
Countermeasure: Require assurance of continuity and coordination across divisions.
Required Action: Consolidate records from all relevant offices and provide a unified response.

2. ADA and Rehabilitation Act Compliance: Equal Access as a Legal Right
As a person with a documented disability, I am entitled to reasonable accommodations under the ADA and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Your failure to provide accessible formats for requested records constitutes discrimination and violates federal law.

Case Law:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004): Agencies must ensure meaningful access to government services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985): Denial of reasonable accommodations creates barriers that violate civil rights.

Required Action:
Provide all requested records in accessible formats, including plain-language summaries or electronic files compatible with assistive technologies.
Confirm compliance with ADA requirements by [specific date].

3. Mandated Reporting and Whistleblower Protections
Your handling of this request implicates broader concerns, including potential fraud, misuse of federal funds, or retaliation against whistleblowers. Under the Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302), you are required to report and address systemic violations.
Countermeasure: Reference Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4), which requires the reporting of observed violations of law.
Required Action: Document and escalate evidence of misconduct to oversight bodies, including the Office of Inspector General (OIG).

4. Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with your statutory obligations knowingly constitutes violations of:
Obstruction of Justice (18 U.S.C. § 1505): Delaying lawful access to records obstructs public accountability.
Civil Rights Violations (42 U.S.C. § 1983): Denying ADA accommodations constitutes a deprivation of federally protected rights.
Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4): Concealing or failing to report observed violations is a criminal act.
Countermeasure: Prepare for judicial review, oversight complaints, and public advocacy if compliance fails.

5. Escalation Pathways
If your office does not comply within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this matter through:
Judicial Review: Filing a lawsuit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel disclosure.
Oversight Complaints: Submitting formal complaints to OGIS, OIG, and the DOJ Civil Rights Division.
Public Advocacy: Engaging investigative journalists, transparency advocates, and public interest organizations to ensure accountability.

6. Final Statement: Upholding Transparency and Accountability
This matter reflects the public’s right to transparency and the preservation of trust in government institutions. Your actions will either affirm your agency’s commitment to accountability or further evidence systemic disregard for these principles.

I look forward to your prompt and substantive response.

David Medeiros

Summary of Responsibilities

Each individual and organization listed plays a crucial role in federal and state oversight, advocacy, and the protection of civil rights. Their functions include but are not limited to:

Oversight & Accountability: Ensuring compliance with federal and state laws, including Medicaid regulations, FOIA, ADA, and civil rights protections.

Transparency & Advocacy: Promoting open government practices and supporting whistleblower activities.

Civil Rights Enforcement: Addressing violations of constitutional and statutory protections against discrimination.

Legislative Oversight: Monitoring government programs and expenditures, particularly those impacting vulnerable populations like Medicaid beneficiaries.

Judicial and Administrative Review: Offering remedies for non-compliance through litigation or administrative actions.

ADA Accommodations Request

This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations

To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.

Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.

Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication

All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.

Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.

Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.

Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.

Identification of Responsible Officers

Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.

Non-Negotiable Compliance

These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank
you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

_______________________________________________

Dear Mr. Medeiros:

This is in further response to your December 26, 2024, Freedom of Information Act
request, received by the Civil Rights Division, seeking access to records pertaining to:

1. OSC Case Records Complete files, internal and external communications,
investigations, and resolutions regarding: DI-25-000310; DI-25-000325; DI-25-
000379; DI-12192024714; DI-12112024134.

2. Interagency Correspondence Communications between OSC, FBI, DOJ, CMS,
HHS, and relevant state agencies regarding: Whistleblower disclosures and
investigations. Enforcement of ADA, Medicaid transparency, and constitutional
compliance. Allegations or investigations into fraud, retaliation, and procedural
violations.

3. FBI Involvement Documentation reflecting FBI’s role in addressing OSC-related
investigations, whistleblower protections, and Medicaid; compliance. Include:
Correspondence with OSC, DOJ, CMS and HHS regarding whistleblower
allegations. Investigative records and findings.

4. DOJ and HHS Oversight DOJ Civil Rights Division and HHS OCR records
related to: ADA compliance investigations. Complaints and procedural
documentation under OCR Transaction Number 01-25-592844. Federal and state
enforcement actions against systemic non-compliance.

5. CMS and Medicaid Audits All internal and external audits, investigations, and
compliance reviews associated with the Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI)
Waiver Program. Documents relating to whistleblower-reported fraud, misuse of
funds, and oversight deficiencies.
Freedom of Information/PA Unit –4CON
950 Pennsylvania Ave., NW
Washington, DC 20530

6. FOIA Compliance Records Metadata, processing logs, and communications
related to this FOIA request, including: Identified responsible officers and internal

procedural reviews.

After a thorough search, I have determined that the Civil Rights Division has no records
pertaining your request.

If you are not satisfied with the Civil Rights Division’s determination in response to this
request, you may administratively appeal by writing to the Director, Office of Information Policy
(OIP), United States Department of Justice, 441 G Street, NW, 6th Floor, Washington, D.C.
20530, or you may submit an appeal through OIP's FOIA STAR portal by creating an account on
the following website: https://www.justice.gov/oip/submit-and-track-request-or-appeal. Your
appeal must be postmarked or electronically transmitted within 90 days of the date of my
response to your request. If you submit your appeal by mail, both the letter and the envelope
should be clearly marked "Freedom of Information Act Appeal."
Additionally, you may contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at
the National Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIA mediation services
they offer. The contact information for OGIS is: Office of Government Information Services,
National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park,
Maryland 20740-6001; e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-
684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. Please reference the FOIA/PA No. above in any
correspondence with OGIS.
I hope the Civil Rights Division has been of some assistance to you in this matter.

Sincerely,

April N. Freeman
April Freeman, FOIA Liaison
Freedom of Information/Privacy Acts Unit
Civil Rights Division

Via Email: requests@muckrock.com Re: Freedom of Information Act and/or Privacy Act Request #FOIA-2025-060 Dear Mr. MEDEIROS: Please be advised that your Freedom of Information Act(FOIA) and/or Privacy Act request to the U.S. Office of Special Counsel (OSC)has been in the request queue pending processing. We acknowledge your request and are committed to communicating with requesters. After an initial review when it was received, your request was placed in our “Simple” track for FOIA requests. (OSC categorizes its FOIA requests in three tracks, “simple,” “complex,” and “expedited.” We then generally process the requests in the order in which they were received within each category). Because your request is Simple and it has been a long time since you made the request, OSC would like to confirm that you are still seeking the records requested. If you find that you no longer need the requested records,please advise BY REPLY EMAIL stating that you longer wish to have your request processed. We will administratively close your request at that time. If you remain interested in the records, please advise BY REPLY EMAIL stating that you wish to have your request processed. You may wish to consider narrowing the scope of your request, which will allow us to provide a response more quickly. If you wish to speak with someone directly, you may contact the FOIA Public Liaison, at 202-804-7000. If we do not receive a response to this message within 30 working days, we will administratively close your request. Thank you for your attention to this matter. We look forward to hearing from you soon! Thank you,

The challenges we face today demand more than acknowledgment—they require action, collaboration, and a unified commitment to solutions. Together, we must embrace transparency, accountability, and compassion as the
foundation of our efforts. By fostering open communication, prioritizing the needs of the most vulnerable, and holding systems accountable, we can rebuild trust and ensure equitable outcomes for all.

Solutions lie in unity—when state and federal leaders, advocates, and communities work hand in hand to uphold justice and fairness. Transparency through accessible Freedom of Information processes, adherence to legal
mandates, and robust oversight are the pillars that support meaningful change. Each of us has a role to play in creating a system that serves and protects.

Our collective mission is clear: to build bridges between agencies and communities, ensure the dignity of every individual, and honor the principles that guide us toward progress. Together, with determination and unity, we can
overcome systemic failures and pave the way for a brighter, more inclusive future.

Americans living with disabilities and their families are Americans—full citizens of this nation, protected by the same Constitution that guarantees the rights and freedoms of every individual. We are not separate, lesser, or forgotten. We are Americans with the same unalienable rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.

We stand firmly on the principles of equality, dignity, and justice. Our voices matter. Our contributions matter. And our rights—our Constitutional rights—must be respected, upheld, and protected without exception or delay.

We are Americans with rights. Period.

David Medeiros

communications.subject: Rhode Island Access to Public Records Act Request: Heritage Restaurant Group (Newport City Clerk)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Rhode Island Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all financial documents related to Heritage Restaurant Group. These records should include, but are not limited to contracts, purchase orders, invoices, receipts, expense reports, travel authorization requests, vouchers, memos, among other documents. I request such records from Jan. 1, 2024 to present.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexa Gagosz

communications.subject: Newport RI APRA Requests
communications.communication:
Good morning,

Please see the file trasnfer link below which will satisfy the two pending requests I have on file.  The link will expire on 3/1.  Please confirm receipt.

Thank you,
Laura

https://ftp.cityofnewport.com/public/folder/mMZHv9qQ4k2-gaxtlkACqA/APRA%20Heritage


Under RIGL 38-28-8, you have the right to appeal a denial of access to records under the APRA to the Chief Administrative Officer of the City of Newport.  The Chief Administrative Officer of the City of Newport is the City Manager, Colin K. Kennedy.  You may also file a complaint with the Department of the Attorney General, 150 South Main Street, Providence, RI 02903 or with the Rhode Island Superior Court for the county where the records are maintained.  Additional information concerning the Access to Public Records Act may be available from the Attorney General's website at www.riag.ri.gov<http://www.riag.ri.gov>.


    Laura C. Swistak, CMC

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Flock Installs (Fontana Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Hello, 

I am requesting records related to the installation, approval, and locations of automatic license plate readers from Motorola and Flock Safety

Emails from: 
Akeia Dixon - installs@flocksafety.com
Dave@flocksafety.com
garrett@flocksafety.com
Motorola email domain names

Do not include promo emails or emails from hello@flocksafety.com

Communications related to installations. 
Keyword search: 
"installations"
"install" 
"technicians"
"public works"
"rebates"

Copies of attachments. 
Copies of documentation of installations that include their locations, approvals by the city for installations, and contracts related to the installations 

Limit search to: 2018 - 2023

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Video Footage, Hamline Elementary
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Video camera footage of all exterior cameras at Hamline Elementary school from 10am through 2:15pm on January 24, 2025. I am not looking for any student specific information; CPS can redact/blur any student faces that appear on video footage in this time frame. 

This request is on behalf of The FOIA Bakery, an Illinois nonprofit. Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fchicago-public-schools-3121%252Fvideo-footage-hamline-elementary-180378%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAATZ164Jy60iQjs6iHTUOyYGcc%3A1tcFFi%3Aauf2nBZPNM8rkTy7zlqcQZzmOVQi5PmtN82rudZ96NM 
 
Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center. 

Track the issue status and respond at: https://cps.mycusthelp.com/WEBAPP//_rs/RequestEdit.aspx?rid=16806

communications.subject: University of Nevada, Reno - Public Records Request PRR-1874-28: Completed
communications.communication:
Dear Requestor,

The request Request Number: PRR-1874-28 has been completed. Please click on the request link to download the responsive documents that have been made available to you.

The University produces the document responsive to PRR 1874-28.  Disciplinary complaints and investigations as well as Title IX and discrimination complaints and investigations of complaints involving employees, if any, are confidential personnel matters and are protected from public disclosure under the Board of Regents Handbook, the NSHE Code (including section 5.6.2) and the common law balancing test.  Donrey v. Bradshaw, 106 Nev. 630, 636, 798 P.2d 144 (1990). The NSHE Code has the force and effect of statute.  State ex rel. Richardson v. Board of Regents, 70 Nev. 144, 150 (1953).  To the extent such complaints and investigations, if any, involve students, they are confidential under the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (“FERPA”), which deems education records of students to be confidential.  See 20 U.S.C. section 1232g(4) and 34 C.F.R. section 99.3 and NSHE BOR Handbook, Title 4, Chapter 1, Section 28.  Such records are also confidential under the common law balancing test.  Donrey v. Bradshaw, 106 Nev. 630, 636, 798 P.2d 144 (1990).  Pursuant to Nev. Rev. Stat. (NRS) 239.010, confidential or privileged records are exempt from public disclosure. UNR relies, in good faith, on this claim of confidentiality and therefore such records, if any, are not subject to production.  NRS 239.0107(d)(2); NRS 239.012.  
  
 Thank you, 
   
 University of Nevada, Reno 
 1664 N. Virginia Street, MS 0208
Reno, NV 89557

communications.communication:

Douglas County has received your County Records Request on 2/1/2025 and given the reference number C002145-020525 for tracking purposes. 
 Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Sincerely,
Rose Terse 
 
Douglas County is in the process of gathering, identifying, reviewing, and assigning your request to the relevant department(s).  The Washington State Public Records Act requires that requests for access to records be responded to within five (5) business days by either providing the records or providing an estimate of time when the records will be available.

Douglas County WA

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: County Records Request of February 01, 2025, Reference # C002145-020525 Dear Rose Terse, Douglas County WA received a public records request from you on February 01, 2025. Requesting the release of the following records: To Whom It May Concern: 
Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 
All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office. 
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 
Sincerely, 
Rose Terse Douglas County WA has reviewed its files and has located responsive records to your request. Please log in to the Public Records Request Center at the following link to retrieve the responsive records. County Records Request - C002145-020525 If you have any questions, believe the County’s response is incomplete, or if I have misunderstood your request, please contact me immediately. We can discuss any errors you believe were made in the County’s response. I am confident I can address any concerns you may have. Our office believes we have provided all records responsive to your request for public records dated 2/1/2025, and now considers your request fulfilled and closed.  Because this office does not intend to further address your request, we are notifying you that the Public Record Act’s one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review pursuant to RCW 42.56.550(6) is now in effect. Sincerely, Tiana Rowland 
Administration

communications.subject: Iowa Open Records Law Request: Responses to RFI# FWBP-CC-24-183, Request for Information for Child Care Assistance Case Management and Payment Systems, Iowa Department of Health and Human Services
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Iowa Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Find responses to RFI# FWBP-CC-24-183, Request for Information for Child Care Assistance Case Management and Payment Systems, Iowa Department of Health and Human Services. Proposals were due on 4/23/2024.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Toni Thompson

communications.subject: Re: Iowa Open Records Law Request: Responses to RFI# FWBP-CC-24-183, Request for Information for Child Care Assistance Case Management and Payment Systems, Iowa Department of Health and Human Services
communications.communication:
Hello Toni,

The Iowa Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has received your open records request and will be back in contact soon.  You may view the Department's open records policy at Open Records Policy<https://hhs.iowa.gov/initiatives/open-records>.

Iowa HHS attempts to determine if we have responsive records that can be released within 10 business days, but it may take longer based on the complexity of your request or workload and staffing issues.  I'll do my best to keep you updated if we will require additional time on this request.

Please let me know if you have any questions at this time.  Thank you for your request.


HHS Open Records

Division of Compliance

Iowa Department of Health and Human Services

321 E 12th St., Des Moines, IA 50319

Hhsopenrecords@hhs.iowa.gov

HHS.Iowa.gov<http://hhs.iowa.gov/>

communications.subject: Re: Iowa Open Records Law Request: Responses to RFI# FWBP-CC-24-183, Request for Information for Child Care Assistance Case Management and Payment Systems, Iowa Department of Health and Human Services
communications.communication:
Hello Toni,



Attached you will find a letter and link, https://hhsfoia.blob.core.windows.net/hhsfoia/A25-173.zip, in response to your record request.  Iowa HHS will consider this request closed at this time.  Thank you for your request.



Iowa HHS is working continuously to improve our processes.  Attached you will find a survey for you to provide feedback on your experience.  We appreciate your time in completing this survey, survey<https://ihhshr.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_1SJ9SYMKOedaKCW>.



HHS Open Records

Division of Compliance

Iowa Department of Health and Human Services

321 E 12th St., Des Moines, IA 50319

Hhsopenrecords@hhs.iowa.gov

HHS.Iowa.gov<http://hhs.iowa.gov/>

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Houston boarding home complaints
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of complaints submitted to the Boarding Homes Investigation Unit since 2018 concerning potential non-permitted boarding homes, sufficient to show:
-The total number of complaints
-The addresses of properties subject to complaints
-Any enforcement action taken pursuant to the complaints

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rebecca Burns

communications.communication:
Dear Rebecca Burns: 
Thank you for your interest in public records of Houston Police Department. Your request has been received and is being processed in accordance with Chapter 552 of Texas Government Code, the Public Information Act. Your request was received in this office on 11/25/2024 and given the reference number P096005-112524 for tracking purposes. Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of complaints submitted to the Boarding Homes Investigation Unit since 2018 concerning potential non-permitted boarding homes, sufficient to show:
-The total number of complaints
-The addresses of properties subject to complaints
-Any enforcement action taken pursuant to the complaints

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rebecca Burns

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fpolice-department-336%252Fhouston-boarding-home-complaints-176880%252F%253Femail%253Dhpd.openrecords%252540houstonpolice.org&url_auth_token=AAAVVJD0KxlBQ1N60poO756rUa8%3A1tFmhx%3Als0l7olJu8SUpCIwYe4rSM8piZhXd4v5NRhVVbmWscg 
Your request will be forwarded to the relevant Houston Police Department department(s) to locate the information you seek and to determine the volume and any costs associated with satisfying your request. You will be contacted about the availability and/or provided with copies of the records in question. PLEASE NOTE: The Chapter 552 of Texas Government Code, the Public Information Act does not require a governmental body to create new information, to do legal research, or to answer questions. 
 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the Houston Public Information Request Center. 
Houston Police Department

communications.subject: [Records Center] Police Department Public Information :: P096005-112524
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of November 25, 2024, Reference # P096005-112524 Dear Rebecca Burns, The Houston Police Department has reviewed its files and has located responsive records to your request. Please log in to the Houston Public Information Request Center at the following link to retrieve the appropriate responsive documents. 
We will release the documents within 24 to 48 hours after the payment is received. If it is a weekend or holiday, then we will release the documents the next business working day. Please note regarding the “total number of complaints”, we have no way of knowing how many complaints the City has received since 2018. That information may be available through the City’s 311 system. Also, regarding enforcement action, the Boarding Home Investigations Unit has issued approximately 2169 citations to unpermitted boarding homes since January of 2018. 
Sincerely, Jasmine Stewart Administrative Specialist Houston Police Department (HPD)

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R006254-020325
communications.communication:
Franklin County Public Records Request 

RE: 5 DAY RESPONSE PURSUANT TO RCW 42.56.520 

REQUEST NO. R006254-020325 

Dear  Rose Terse, 

Franklin County is in receipt of your Public Records Request dated 2/3/2025 and received on 02/01/2025 for "Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 
All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office. 
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.". 
Your request has been assigned Public Records Request Number R006254-020325. Please refer to this number in any future correspondence regarding this request. 

We are in the process of gathering, identifying, and reviewing records responsive to your request but we need additional time to respond the high volume of records requested. 

We estimate we will be able to provide you with the records or a first installment on or around 02/19/25. 

Thank you for contacting Franklin County. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact my office at 509-546-5854 or recordsoffice@franklincountywa.gov. 
Sincerely, 

Lizette Parra

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R006254-020325
communications.communication:
Franklin County Public Records Request 

RE: REQUEST NO. R006254-020325 IS NOW CLOSED 

Dear  Rose Terse, 

The Franklin County Public Records Office has processed your public records request, received on 02/01/2025. 

The records that are responsive to your request for, “Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 
All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office. 
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.,” are being provided to you, today, 02/06/2025, via GovQA Portal. 

As your records have been delivered, your request, R006254-020325, is now considered closed. If you are dissatisfied with our response, pursuant to RCW 42.56.550(6), you may file an appeal to the Franklin County Prosecutor’s Office, Civil Division. You have one year from today’s date, 02/06/2025, to file. You may contact the Prosecutor’s Office at 509-545-3543 with any questions or concerns you have at this time. 
Sincerely, 

Lizette Parra

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Patron Incident Reports - August 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

All Patron Incident Reports submitted for the Area Manager 5 North Region in August 2023.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit Lucy Parsons Labs for the purpose of public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexandra Gelzin

communications.subject: FOIA Request 2019-01586
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Neiss


This is in response to  your 27 January 2020, Freedom of Information Act request documents relating to "I request an electronic copy of the logo for the United States Space Force tweeted out this afternoon by the President in SVG or EPS file format.

We contacted the USSF for responsive records and were notified the records you are seeking are publicly available by accessing https://www.spaceforce.mil/About-Us/About-Space-Force/USSF-Symbols/, and https://www.spaceforce.mil/News/Article/2282948/the-us-space-force-logo-and-motto/

Please direct your questions to Janet Beasley at (703) 614-3025 or janet.beasley@us.af.mil<mailto:janet.beasley@us.af.mil> and reference case number 2019-01586-F.


V/r

//SIGNED//
JANET F. BEASLEY, DAF GS-12
Government Information Specialist/Paralegal
Headquarters Air Force Information Office (SAF/AAII)
DSN: 224-3025
Commercial: 703-614-3025
I have migrated to CHES. My new email address is Janet.beasley@us.af.mil<mailto:Janet.beasley@us.af.mil>
Workflow:  SAF.AA.HAF.FOIA.workflow@us.af.mil<mailto:SAF.AA.HAF.FOIA.workflow@us.af.mil>.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2020-01586-F
communications.communication:
The documents released are not responsive to my request. I asked for the Space Force logo in its original SVG or EPS file format. 

A modified version of the original government document can be found at the link provided below with the note "The U.S. Space Force seal is reserved for internal, official use only and marked here to discourage unauthorized use. ": https://www.spaceforce.mil/About-Us/About-Space-Force/USSF-Symbols/

I am asking for that original logo itself in the format in which it was initially created by or for the government, which again, will likely be SVG or EPS.

files.title: RESPONSE FOIA Request 2019-01586
files.source: Air Force, United States of America

title: Data on school-based arrests (Marlborough Police Department)

communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern:  
  

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department. 

Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

  

I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth):  

  

1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:  

a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement  

b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement  

c. Charge (or charges)  

d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement  

e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement  

f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement  

g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement  

h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement  

i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement  

j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school. 

k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and  

l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.  

  

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).  

  

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).  

  

4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.  

  

5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).   

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”  

  

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.  

Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).  

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety. 

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.  

  

Sincerely,  

Katherine Stathulis

J.D. Research Fellow

Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration 

Northeastern University School of Law

k.stathulis@northeastern.edu
  
617-373-5862

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Data on school-based arrests (Marlborough Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Requester:

In response to your public records request, on behalf of the records access officer(s) and records custodians of the Police Department, I am writing to inform you that the responsive records from the Marlborough Public School District are attached. This e-mail completes the Police Department's response to your request.

You have the right to make an administrative appeal to the Supervisor of Public Records under 950 CMR 32.08 (1) and the right to seek judicial review by commencing a civil action in the Superior Court. Contact information for the Records Access Officer is: Ashley Cartier - Principal Clerk - Records, Marlborough Police Department, Marlborough, MA 01752, Phone: 508-485-1212 and Email: acartier@marlborough-ma.gov<mailto:acartier@marlborough-ma.gov>.

Respectfully,


Ashley Cartier
Principal Clerk
Marlborough Police Dept.
Phone: 508-485-1212 Ext. 36975

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Nassau County PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Nassau County Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Gelardi

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Nassau County PD Grant Applications
communications.communication:
Dear Chris Gelardi:



This will acknowledge receipt of your request for records under the Freedom of Information Law received by the Division of Criminal Justice Services on March 22, 2024. The request was for "All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Nassau County Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present."



Your request has been forwarded to the appropriate program area(s) to identify documents that are responsive to your request and which may be made available pursuant to all applicable provisions of the Freedom of Information Law.



A determination as to whether your request is granted or denied will be reached in approximately 20 business days or we will notify you in writing if the responsible program area(s) should require additional time to locate, assemble and review documents that may be responsive to your request.



Please note that, pursuant to Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, a charge may be applied to your request, including the actual cost of the medium used to respond to your Freedom of Information Law request and/or other related costs.  When responsive records have been identified, you will be informed of any cost and how payment should be made.







Very truly yours,


Brian Garvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer

This is in response to your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request for "All applications for grants submitted to DCJS by the Nassau County Police Department between January 1, 2010 and the present."

Please find links to 2 PDF documents below that are responsive to your request. Please note that pursuant to Sections 87(2)(b) and 87(2)(e)(iv) of the Public Officers Law (POL), certain portions have been redacted for personal privacy and to not reveal criminal investigative techniques or procedures.

Brian Garvey, Esq.
