communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Police Settlements (Kern County Counsel)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of all reports, lists, databases, or individual documents created since 1/1/16 detail lawsuits brought against the city's police department. This should include any documentation mechanism your department uses to track lawsuits. It should also include any documents your department submits to local, state, or federal agencies listing the number and/or status of lawsuits brought against the police department.

This request should be construed to include documents compiled quarterly, annually, or in other increments as well as documents or databases that contain responsive information over a longer time span.

Please provide all available materials from January 1, 2016 through November 6, 2024.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

communications.subject: CPRA request
communications.communication:
Hello, I'm in receipt of a request to Kern County for "police records."  I'd like to clarify with you:  we don't represent the Bakersfield Police Department, that CPRA would be directed to the City of Bakersfield.  Did you mean this to be directed to the Kern County Sheriff's office for sheriff records?
Please let me know, thank you--





Kathleen Rivera, Chief Deputy County Counsel
1115 Truxtun Avenue, Fourth Floor
Bakersfield, CA 93301
Direct Line: (661) 868-3820<tel:6618683820>
krivera@<mailto:krivera@co.kern.ca.us>kerncounty.com

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Police Settlements (Kern County Counsel)
communications.communication:
Yes, the Kern County Sheriffs. 

Thank you,
Joey

communications.subject: Re: California Public Records Act Request: Police Settlements (Kern County Counsel)
communications.communication:
Thank you for that clarification.

This e mail is in response to your CPRA, regarding sheriff records, sent electronically on 11/6/24 to our County Counsel at mraison@kerncounty.com.  This request asked for police records.  I e mailed you on 11/18 asking if you meant to request sheriff records, as we do not represent the police department.  You responded on 11/19 that yes, you meant sheriff records.

The County is unable to fully respond to your request within the 10-day statutory time period. Due to the following “unusual circumstances,” the County will need additional time as provided by California Government Code section 7922.535:
(1) The need to search for and collect the requested records from field facilities or other establishments that are separate from the office processing the request.
(2) The need to search for, collect, and appropriately examine a voluminous amount of separate and distinct records that are demanded in a single request.
(3) The need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, among two or more components of the agency having substantial subject matter interest therein.
I will respond to your requests further by December5 , 2024.
If you have any questions regarding the County’s response to your requests, you may contact me at (661) 868-3820, or  email at krivera@kerncounty.com.
Respectfully,


Kathleen Rivera, Chief Deputy County Counsel
1115 Truxtun Avenue, Fourth Floor
Bakersfield, CA 93301
Direct Line: (661) 868-3820<tel:6618683820>
krivera@<mailto:krivera@co.kern.ca.us>kerncounty.com

communications.subject: CPRA request
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Scott:
This letter is in response to your request for public records, dated November 7, 2024, and delivered to the County of Kern (“County”) via electronic mail.   This is an update to my previous letter to you.  County staff have consulted in relation to your request and have begun to search for the requested records. The County will need additional time as provided by California Government Code section 7922.535 due to the following “unusual circumstances:”
the need to search for and collect the requested records from field facilities or other establishments that are separate from the office processing the request; and the need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, among two or more components of the agency having substantial subject matter interest therein.
The County will respond to your requests further by January 6, 2025.If you have any questions regarding the County’s response to your requests, you may contact me at (661) 868-3820, or by email at krivera@kerncounty.com<mailto:krivera@kerncounty.com>. Please note the County is closed for winter recess Dec. 24th-Jan. 1st.

Kathleen Rivera, Chief Deputy County Counsel
1115 Truxtun Avenue, Fourth Floor
Bakersfield, CA 93301
Direct Line: (661) 868-3820<tel:6618683820>
krivera@<mailto:krivera@co.kern.ca.us>kerncounty.com

communications.subject: [NYS OAG FOIL Request Center] General FOIL Request :: G000474-071823
communications.communication:
July 25, 2023 
RE:  Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Request Reference # G000474-071823 
Dear Mr. Mellins: 
This email is in response to the above-referenced FOIL request. 
Please be advised that Public Officers Law § 89(3)(a) provides that a request for records shall reasonably describe the records sought.  Your request does not reasonably describe records and requires the following clarification(s): 
Please clarify whether “currently uncollected monies,” as referenced in your request, includes items with future pay dates. 
You may submit your clarification by accessing this request in the NYS OAG FOIL Request Center.  If you do not clarify your request within ten business days, we will consider this FOIL request closed. 
Sincerely, Abisola Fatade Assistant Attorney General 
 
Please visit the NYS OAG FOIL Request Center to view frequently asked questions, monitor request progress, and submit future requests. U5vg-2BnVMFOn-2BpwFVqbQTWVBc2VPbQTb604E6YT2XeYlfTR8ZY0RCny-2BFGIJdbl3SFAT7wO)

communications.subject: [NYS OAG FOIL Request Center] General FOIL Request :: G000474-071823
communications.communication: August 3, 2023 RE:  Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Request Reference # G000474-071823 Dear Mr. Mellins: Pursuant to Public Officers Law §89(3)(a), the Office of the Attorney General acknowledges receipt of your clarification of the above-referenced FOIL request. We are performing a diligent search for the records you request.  We will notify you of the status of your request on or before August 31, 2023. If we should locate any documents that respond to your request, and if we provide them in electronic format, we will notify you of any fee in advance.  If we provide paper copies, we will also notify you of any fee in advance; for paper copies, the first five pages would be provided free of charge, and the cost for the remaining pages would be $.25 per page. Sincerely, Abisola Fatade Assistant Attorney General

communications.communication:
July 26, 2024 RE:  Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Request Reference # G000474-071823 Dear Mr. Mellins: This email is in response to the above-­referenced FOIL request. The Office of the Attorney General has conducted a diligent search for the records that you have requested. Please access this request in the NYS OAG FOIL Request Center to retrieve records that respond to your request.  Please be advised that portions of the records that respond to your request are exempt from disclosure and have been redacted pursuant to: • Public Officers Law § 87(2)(a), which provides that records that are exempted from disclosure by state or federal statute are exempt from disclosure under FOIL.  The records constitute protected health information, which is exempt from disclosure under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (“HIPAA”) and New York State Public Health Law § 18; and • Public Officers Law § 87(2)(b), because their disclosure would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy. You have a right to appeal the foregoing decision.  If you elect to do so, you must appeal in writing, within 30 days, to Kathryn Sheingold, Records Appeals Officer.  Your appeal can be sent by email to or by mail to State of New York, Office of the Attorney General, Division of Appeals and Opinions, The Capitol, Albany, New York 12224.  You can reach the Records Appeals Officer by telephone at (518) 776-2009. (mailto:FOIL.Appeals@ag.ny.gov) FOIL.Appeals@ag.ny.gov This is our third and final response to the above-referenced request. Accordingly, this FOIL request is now closed. Sincerely, Abisola Fatade Assistant Attorney General 
 
Please visit the NYS OAG FOIL Request Center to view frequently asked questions, monitor request progress, and submit future requests. 
 View this request in the My Request Center.

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (February 2025) (Island County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: FOIA Request: Fusus logs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

1) User manuals, handbooks, or comparable instructional documents provided to the department by Fusus regarding the following Fusus products and services:
- FususONE (https://www.fusus.com/rtc3-products/fususone)
- FususCORE (https://www.fusus.com/rtc3-products/fususcore)
- FususREGISTRY (https://www.fusus.com/rtc3-products/fususregistry)
- Fusus AI Video Analytics (https://www.fusus.com/rtc3-products/fusus-ai)
- Fusus Intelligent AI Alerts (https://www.fusus.com/rtc3-products/fusus-ai)

2) Audit logs/audit trails documenting each time a department account has accessed live or recorded video footage through the Fusus platforms from 1/1/2024 until the date this request is processed.

3) Metadata for each Intelligent AI Alert generated by the department's Fusus system from 1/1/2024 until the date this request is processed. Fusus Intelligent AI Alerts automatically notify authorized users when Fusus AI-connected cameras detect pre-defined events (e.g. a fight) or profiles (e.g. a vehicle of interest). Please note that I am not requesting the video footage or any personally identifying information associated with the alert, but rather the metadata. Metadata may include, but is not limited to: the type of alert, the date and time of the alert, who received the alert, locations associated with the alert, and algorithmic confidence scores associated with the alert. This metadata should be stored in a database and so I ask that you provide it to me as a .csv, .xls, or other database filetype.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

communications.communication:

The exemptions: 1)User manuals, handbooks, or comparable instructional documents provided to the department by Fusus regarding the following Fusus products and services Denied5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a): Under FOIA, information that is protected from disclosure by state or federal law cannot be disclosed pursuant to FOIA. 5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a). Copyright material is protected under Section 106 of the Copyright Act (17 U.S.C. § 106) and, therefore, cannot be disclosed without authorization 2) Audit logs/audit trails documenting each time a department account has accessed live or recorded video footage through the Fusus platforms from 1/1/2024 until the date this request is processed. All months, except February will be made available. There is an open ticket with the vendor to troubleshoot why February data won’t query. I was able to remove empty columns to have data print on one page. I also removed license plates under and IP addresses as 7 1(b), private information and 140/7(1)(d)(v) (v) disclose unique or specialized investigative techniques other than those generally used and known or disclose internal documents of correctional agencies related to detection, observation, or investigation of incidents of crime or misconduct, and disclosure would result in demonstrable harm to the agency or public body that is the recipient of the request; 3) Metadata for each Intelligent AI Alert generated by the department's Fusus system from 1/1/2024 until the date this request is processed. Fusus Intelligent AI Alerts automatically notify authorized users when Fusus AI-connected cameras detect pre-defined events (e.g. a fight) or profiles (e.g. a vehicle of interest). Please note that I am not requesting the video footage or any personally identifying information associated with the alert, but rather the metadata. Metadata may include, but is not limited to: the type of alert, the date and time of the alert, who received the alert, locations associated with the alert, and algorithmic confidence scores associated with the alert. This metadata should be stored in a database and so I ask that you provide it to me as a .csv, .xls, or other database filetype. Item number 3 will be denied applying the following exemptions: 140/7(1)(d)(v) (v) disclose unique or specialized investigative techniques other than those generally used and known or disclose internal documents of correctional agencies related to detection, observation, or investigation of incidents of crime or misconduct, and disclosure would result in demonstrable harm to the agency or public body that is the recipient of the request; (vi) endanger the life or physical safety of law enforcement personnel or any other person; (vii) obstruct an ongoing criminal investigation by the agency that is the recipient of the request. (d-7) Information gathered, or records created from the use of automatic license plate readers in connection with Section 2-130 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. I will email this to your email. I didn't receive a password to add to Muckrock. Responsible Official. Maureen Schmidt, a FOIA Officer for the Village, is the official responsible for this denial. Notice of Right to Judicial Review. Under Section 11 of the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/11, you have the right to seek judicial review of this denial. The Village cannot advise or represent you in this matter. You should consult your own legal counsel. * JanFususAuditRpt.pdf * MarchFususAuditRpt.pdf * AprilFususAuditRpt.pdf * MayFususAuditRpt.pdf * JuneFususAuditRpt.pdf * JulyFususAuditRpt.pdf * AugFususAuditRpt.pdf * SeptFususAuditRpt.pdf * OctFususAudit.pdf Document links are valid for one month. I also removed license plates under and IP addresses as 7 1(b), private information and 140/7(1)(d)(v) (v) disclose unique or specialized investigative techniques other than those generally used and known or disclose internal documents of correctional agencies related to detection, observation, or investigation of incidents of crime or misconduct, and disclosure would result in demonstrable harm to the agency or public body that is the recipient of the request;

3) Metadata for each Intelligent AI Alert generated by the department's Fusus system from 1/1/2024 until the date this request is processed. Fusus Intelligent AI Alerts automatically notify authorized users when Fusus AI-connected cameras detect pre-defined events (e.g. a fight) or profiles (e.g. a vehicle of interest). Please note that I am not requesting the video footage or any personally identifying information associated with the alert, but rather the metadata. Metadata may include, but is not limited to: the type of alert, the date and time of the alert, who received the alert, locations associated with the alert, and algorithmic confidence scores associated with the alert. This metadata should be stored in a database and so I ask that you provide it to me as a .csv, .xls, or other database filetype.

Item number 3 will be denied applying the following exemptions: 140/7(1)(d)(v) (v) disclose unique or specialized investigative techniques other than those generally used and known or disclose internal documents of correctional agencies related to detection, observation, or investigation of incidents of crime or misconduct, and disclosure would result in demonstrable harm to the agency or public body that is the recipient of the request;

(vi) endanger the life or physical safety of law enforcement personnel or any other person;

(vii) obstruct an ongoing criminal investigation by the agency that is the recipient of the request.

(d-7) Information gathered, or records created from the use of automatic license plate readers in connection with Section 2-130 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.

I will email this to your email. I didn't receive a password to add to Muckrock.

Responsible Official. Maureen Schmidt, a FOIA Officer for the Village, is the official responsible for this denial.

Notice of Right to Review by Illinois Attorney General. You have the right to file a request for review of your request and this Notice of Denial by the Public Access Counselor of the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. The Public Access Counselor may be contacted at 500 South 2nd Street, Springfield, Illinois 62701, or by telephone at (877) 299-3642.

Notice of Right to Judicial Review. Under Section 11 of the Illinois Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/11, you have the right to seek judicial review of this denial. The Village cannot advise or represent you in this matter. You should consult your own legal counsel.

Sincerely,

Maureen Schmidt
Records Supervisor
Police Department
Village of Arlington Heights,IL

O:847-368-5319
www.vah.com<http://www.vah.com/>

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: GORA Request: Labat & Talitrix
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All email communications where Patrick Labat is either the sender, recipient, CC'ed, or BCC'ed, sent between the dates of 1/1/2022 and 10/23/2023 and containing at least one of the following keywords: "Talitrix", "electronic monitoring" or "contract." Please include any variations that are not case sensitive. Please include all email attachments.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

Additional information is required to fulfill your open records request. Please provide the following: 
1. Date range: Please provide a specific date range for this search (e.g. "March 1, 2023 - March 31, 2023" or "September 4, 2020") 
2. Name or email address of sender/receiver: We only have access to Fulton County employees’ email boxes. We cannot search the emails of non-employees unless they previously sent a email to or received an email from a Fulton County employee. Please narrow your request and provide the specific names or emails of the Fulton County employees you are referencing in your request. Please also provide the email address of anyone that is not a Fulton County employee. 
3. Keyword search terms that you would like captured in your search: We cannot fulfill your request without keyword search terms. Please be very specific, otherwise we will have to guess as to what you are asking for and you may not receive all of the emails you are seeking. (e.g. "court" or "police station") 
Once we have received the information requested above, we will forward your request to our IT department so that they may conduct the search. 
Your request will be paused for 10 days while clarification is pending. If we do not receive a response within that time frame, your request will be withdrawn. Once we receive the required information, we will forward your request to the IT department so that they can run the search.*****

November 30, 2023 
SENT VIA EMAIL: 
Dear e e: 
This correspondence is in response to your Open Records Act Request Reference#: R009160-102423 dated October 24, 2023.  Your request sought the following: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All email communications where Patrick Labat is either the sender, recipient, CC'ed, or BCC'ed, sent between the dates of 1/1/2022 and 10/23/2023 and containing at least one of the following keywords: "Talitrix", "electronic monitoring" or "contract." Please include any variations that are not case sensitive. Please include all email attachments. 

There are a total of 2924 emails to review. The cost for this request will be $964.07. This cost represents 48 hours of review and redaction at a rate of $20.19/hour. The first 15 minutes of service has been waived. 
The following information may be exempt/redacted: 

Social security numbers, mother’s birth name, credit card, debit card, bank account, account or utility account passwords and numbers, financial data, insurance and medical records, unlisted telephone numbers, personal e-mail address or cellular telephone number, day and month of birth, and information regarding public utility, television, internet, or telephone accounts held by private customers, O.C.G.A. 50-18-72(a)(20)); 

Records that reveal a public employee’s home address, home telephone number, day and month of birth, social security number, insurance or medical information, mother’s birth name, credit card information, debit card information, bank account information, account number, utility account number, password used to access accounts, financial data or information other than compensation by a government agency, unlisted telephone number, and identity of the public employee’s immediate family members or dependents, O.C.G.A. 50-18-72 (a)(21); 

Communications subject to attorney-client privilege, O.C.G.A. 50-18-72 (a)(41);and 

Confidential attorney work product, O.C.G.A. 50-18-72 (a)(42) 

Because this amount exceeds $500.00, a prepayment will be required before we will begin working on this request. 

Please make your check/money order in the amount of $964.07 payable to Fulton County Government and note reference # R009160-102423 on your payment. You may send to the address below: 

Office of the Fulton County Attorney 
Attn: Open Records 
141 Pryor Street, Suite 4038 
Atlanta, GA 30303 

Your request will be paused while payment is pending. If we do not receive a response or payment within 10 business days, the request will be withdrawn. 
Feel free to contact us, if you have any questions. 

Best Regards, 

Open Records Team

communications.subject: RE: Georgia Open Records Act Request #R009160-102423
communications.communication:
Thank you.

May I amend my request to the following?

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Metadata of all email communications where Patrick Labat is either the sender, recipient, CC'ed, or BCC'ed, sent between the dates of 1/1/2022 and 10/23/2023 and containing at least one of the following keywords: "Talitrix", "electronic monitoring" or "contract." Please include any variations that are not case sensitive. 

The specific metadata data points I'm interested in are: to address(es), from address, cc address(es), bcc address(es), sent date/time, received date/time, subject line, and names of all attachments. This request does not seek the contents of the emails themselves, and only the specified email metadata. Please provide me with the records in an Excel format.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

title: Agency Roster (Glendale City Clerk for PD)

communications.subject: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Agency Roster (Glendale City Clerk for PD)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Furniture purchases
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Records and communications about purchases of furniture for the Charlotte and William Bloomberg Medford Public Library, including communications with vendors.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jim Kang

title: Contracts with Private Investigations Firms (Palm Springs Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Contracts with Private Investigations Firms (Palm Springs Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current contracts between the police department and private investigation and/or background investigation companies.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

William Frederick

communications.subject: Records Request Confirmation
communications.communication:
The City Clerk’s Office is in receipt of your Public Records Request.  Please note that the City of Palm Springs has up to ten (10) calendar days to respond to your request, or the next business day thereafter. If needed, an extension may be requested as the City works to compile all responsive records. Should our office need further clarification on your request, we will be in contact with you. 
  
 
Your request security key is 38A96E7E.
Your request reference number is Request Number: PD-57-2025.

Please have this security key and reference number available when communicating with our staff regarding your request.

communications.subject: Public Records Request PD-57-2025 Completed
communications.communication:
Good afternoon, 
  
 Some Information has been redacted pursuant to Government Code §7922.000.   
  
 An agency shall justify withholding any record by demonstrating that the record in question is exempt under express provisions of this division, or that on the facts of the particular case the public interest served by not disclosing the record clearly outweighs the public interest served by disclosure of the record. 
  
 Within the documents, City staff members have redacted personal information, such as personal email addresses, personal phone numbers, insurance policy numbers, Vehicle Identification Numbers (VIN) and familial vehicle insurance information. Public disclosure of the redacted personal information would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy. Based on the reasons for the redactions, the public interest served by withholding the redacted information clearly outweighs any public interest served by disclosure (Gov. Code § 7922.000). 
  
   
  
 We have completed your request. If you requested paper copies to be picked up, you may visit us during business hours to retrieve; if you asked for your copies to be mailed, they will be sent on the next business day; if you requested electronic copies, they can be retrieved from the public portal linked below. 
  
 Link: https://url4102.request.justfoia.com/ls/click?upn=u001.nrfdmL-2B1UhWpB4V2ArB2se8BjD2b1xL-2BdZXBnCB-2BujEToPpZMOaqdQFUKaDn3waQ-2BnIWs2WJj2r7fffurA-2B7AwWJU2mwZlMrGmrMDUc79MM-3D09If_ZthzjqYGvE-2BFT4r-2F7v6u4gi4aVx8TvP-2FBWJvi73HQq1h1ueysmTR4nyZdkCl5kwc-2FH0E5JPSD2QUmrSai-2F5S8xoSqC7P3qF-2BRt-2BrbqjTGSLMYpFIzjr5BQjuCcqBKMOVoF6LbqMtN32RSTjR6RTDSU2t451gID6MEv2WO1Pd9GX00xHtWp7LcML0LFHWbJBUTaOTahEdaXRvlHsoxcctsPCVardF3TjdPfmG-2FVwiisKOf0MFJoV1IroZ7s9acBTvp3-2FKHPUSn80-2FhfO8pSfsdyUjEwWND79T-2FOKB70fAtdSjnHsQt5zTFEtCp6P9G35Q

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Custom Plate Banned Words (Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Procedures on handling Banned words  ,symbols or ideals for custom motor vehicle  license plates and a list of banned words or combination of the effect  or symbols which is disallowed for use please include any digital , paper copy or pantalets  which would pertain to  policies or procedures .

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

This request is filed by Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Jordan.

communications.subject: Re: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Custom Plate Banned Words (Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles)
communications.communication:
Tom Nash with Jordan,

The Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) received your request for
information on March 28, 2022, pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of
Information Act (FOIA).  Specifically, you seek:

1.       Procedures on handling Banned words ,symbols or ideals for custom
motor vehicle license plates

2.       a list of banned words or combination of the effect or symbols
which is disallowed for use

In response to request number 1, after a review of DMV’s records, attached
you will find the New Revised Personalized Plate Issuance Guidelines.

In response to request number 2, DMV has provided a list of rejected
personalized plates for 2019, 2020, and 2021 through mid-October. As part
of an update to procedures, DMV stop maintaining this list in October 2021.
If you wish to seek any additional years, the raw data needed to provide
the plates, is contained in DMV’s computer database.  DMV is able to
compile data and run reports to create a record providing the information
you seek in this request.  To do so would require the expenditure of
resources, for which DMV would charge a fee to recover its actual costs
based on an hourly rate for the responding employee’s time plus any
programming, data and duplication costs.  DMV will provide you a cost
estimate to produce a report containing this information. If you would like
to proceed with an ad hoc request to obtain the information you seek,
please complete the attached form and contact Tara Pyatt, Use Agreement
Program and Compliance Manager, via email at tara.pyatt@dmv.virginia.gov.
She will be able to assist you with that process.

Thank you,

DMV FOIA Office

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Agency Roster
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current annual salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

Your request was created on 12/16/2024 and given the reference number P062938-121624 for tracking purposes. Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;

- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current annual salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd 
Your request will be processed by the Police Department to locate the document(s) you seek. If there are any necessary costs associated with your request, you will be contacted with a cost breakdown; payment is required prior to commencing the work required to fulfill your request. Please note that the duty to comply with requests for records extends to those records that exist and are in the possession, custody, or control of the custodian of records at the time of the request. See M.G.L. c. 66, section 10(a)(ii). In addition, 32 Op. Att’y Gen 157, 165 (May 18, 1977) held that a custodian is not obligated to create a record in response to a request for information. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the Public Records Center. 
City of Worcester

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Agency Roster
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

communications.subject: Police Public Records Request :: P062695-121024
communications.communication:
Dear Marcus Boyd: 
Thank you for your public records request. Your request has been received by City of Worcester and is being processed in accordance with the Massachusetts Public Records Law. Your request was created on 12/10/2024 and given the reference number P062695-121024 for tracking purposes. Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fworcester-police-department-611%252Fagency-roster-177417%252F%253Femail%253Dwpd%252540worcesterma.gov&url_auth_token=AAAPJyNswOhN6IRE5E4xrkIv9aE%3A1tLCfw%3APQxW_tBAc1x-vsB9t0LhQoHlDv7j0yOZwBDeKsXMXwg 
Your request will be processed by the Police Department to locate the document(s) you seek. If there are any necessary costs associated with your request, you will be contacted with a cost breakdown; payment is required prior to commencing the work required to fulfill your request. Please note that the duty to comply with requests for records extends to those records that exist and are in the possession, custody, or control of the custodian of records at the time of the request. See M.G.L. c. 66, section 10(a)(ii). In addition, 32 Op. Att’y Gen 157, 165 (May 18, 1977) held that a custodian is not obligated to create a record in response to a request for information. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the Public Records Center. 
City of Worcester

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: MPIA Request for IAD Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I am hereby requesting access to the records listed below and held by the Worcester County Sheriff:

- Copies of any and all internal affairs complaints, including internal, citizen, or other agency complaints for former Deputy Sheriff Gregory Wetzel (0194).
- Complete investigative files for each complaint, including but not limited to reports of recorded statements, video surveillance or body camera footage, investigative files, witness interviews, and photographs.
- The investigative findings of each complaint.
- Any correspondence from the Civilian Review Board, Police Advisory Commission or other civilian police oversight board.
- The final disposition of each case, if any.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. Alternatively, please consider waiving any fees, pursuant to § 4-206(e)(2)(ii) of the General Provisions Article, as this request is on behalf of individuals served by the Maryland Office of the Public Defender, a state government agency, which solely serves indigent citizens of Maryland. As a result, my request for the above-listed public records is in the public interest.  I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Amelia McDonell-Parry
Maryland Office of the Public Defender
Special Litigation Unit
Amelia.McDonell-Parry@maryland.gov

FOIA staff will review your request to determine whether it has sufficient information to be processed;

communications.subject: FDA Receipt of FOI Request
communications.communication:
Harry Duty Harry Duty 
Re: Confirmation # FDA2062272 
Requester Ctrl #: 
In Reply refer to: 2020-1248 
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has received your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request for records regarding: 
FDA records for or relating to HPP being a kill step for pet food and/or raw pet food 
We will respond as soon as possible and may charge you a fee for processing your request. If your informational needs change, and you no longer need the requested records, please contact us to cancel your request, as charges may be incurred once processing of your request has begun. For more information on processing fees, please see http://www.fda.gov/RegulatoryInformation/FOI/FOIAFees/default.htm. 
Due to an increase in the number of incoming requests, we may be unable to comply with the twenty-working-day time limit in this case, as well as the ten additional days provided by the FOIA. The actual processing time will depend on the complexity of your request and whether sensitive records, voluminous records, extensive search, and/or consultation with other HHS components or other executive branch agencies are involved. Please note that requests for medical device approval records (e.g. 510K, PMA, DEN) may take up to 18 to 24 months to process. 
If you have any questions about your request, please call Rochelle A. Coleman, Information Technician at 301-796-8982 or write to us at:

title: Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program Records (Office Of Policy And Management)

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program Records (Office Of Policy And Management)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Freedom of Information Officers
Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program Records

Dear Freedom of Information Officers,

I am writing to formally request access to all records under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552) and relevant Connecticut state laws, specifically related to the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. This information is critical to my participation in the oversight and administration of this program.

In accordance with Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I am requesting accommodations due to my condition. I respectfully request that all records be provided electronically via email, as opposed to portals or complex delivery methods, to ensure full and equal access to the information.

Scope of Request:
Legislative Records:

All bills, amendments, resolutions, legislative proposals, and legislative history related to the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Voting records of all state and federal legislators on any legislation affecting the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Minutes, transcripts, and audio/video recordings of meetings, hearings, or discussions where the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program was a topic.
Public Records:

Comprehensive reports, studies, assessments, and evaluations on the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Budget allocations, financial statements, expenditure reports, and audit results related to the program, pursuant to Connecticut Budget Transparency Laws (C.G.S. § 4-66 and related sections).
All contracts, agreements, memoranda of understanding, and intergovernmental agreements involving the administration or management of the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Correspondence:

All emails, letters, and other forms of communication, including internal and external, regarding the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Internal memoranda, briefing documents, policy directives, and decision-making correspondence related to the oversight and implementation of the program.
Personnel Records:

Non-confidential employment records, including job descriptions, resumes, and performance evaluations, of individuals involved in the administration and oversight of the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program. This request is consistent with the Privacy Act of 1974 (5 U.S.C. § 552a), which protects confidential personal data.
Organizational charts detailing the structure and personnel responsible for managing the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program within relevant state and federal agencies.
Program Information:

All guidelines, protocols, procedural documents, and compliance reviews governing the operation of the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program, as mandated by Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Regulations (42 CFR § 440.180) for home and community-based services waiver programs.
Implementation plans, performance metrics, outcome reports, and evaluation summaries regarding the effectiveness of the program.
Comprehensive data sets related to enrollment, utilization, demographic information, and outcomes of beneficiaries participating in the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Special Requests:
Expedited Processing: Pursuant to Executive Order 13392, which mandates the improvement of agency disclosure processes, and the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552), I request expedited processing of this FOIA request due to the public interest and personal impact of the information.

Electronic Records: In compliance with my rights under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and the ADA, I request that all records be provided in electronic format and sent directly to my email address. This will ensure that I can access the information without unnecessary barriers or delays.

Fee Waiver Request:
I request a waiver of all fees associated with this FOIA request under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). This request is made in the public interest and not for commercial use. The disclosure of the requested information will significantly contribute to public understanding of government operations, particularly concerning the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program, which impacts a vulnerable population. Additionally, due to my condition, as covered by Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, a fee waiver will ensure equitable access to this important information.

Relevant Laws:
This FOIA request, and the accommodations I am requesting, are governed by the following laws and regulations:

Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552) – Governing the right to request access to federal records.
Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.) – Ensuring equal access for individuals with disabilities, including in communication.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794) – Prohibiting discrimination based on disability in programs receiving federal funding.
Privacy Act of 1974 (5 U.S.C. § 552a) – Protecting personal privacy in records maintained by federal agencies.
Medicaid Statute (Title XIX of the Social Security Act) (42 U.S.C. § 1396 et seq.) – Governing Medicaid programs, including waivers like the ABI Waiver.
Connecticut Freedom of Information Act (C.G.S. §§ 1-200 to 1-242) – Governing the right to request access to state records.
Connecticut Budget Transparency Laws (C.G.S. § 4-66) – Requiring public disclosure of state budget allocations and financial reports.
CMS Regulations (42 CFR § 440.180) – Governing the administration of home and community-based services waiver programs, including the ABI Waiver.
Executive Order 13392 ("Improving Agency Disclosure of Information") – Mandating federal agencies to improve FOIA processing.
Non-Waiver of Rights:
This request does not waive any rights I may have under FOIA, the ADA, the Rehabilitation Act, or any other applicable law, and I reserve all rights regarding this matter.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this request and for accommodating my needs.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources

Departments of Submission:
State of Connecticut Agencies:
Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS)
Email: foia.dss@ct.gov
Department: Department of Social Services

Connecticut Office of the Attorney General
Email: attorney.general@ct.gov
Department: Office of the Attorney General

Connecticut General Assembly (CGA)
Email: foia@cga.ct.gov
Department: Connecticut General Assembly

Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM)
Email: opm.foia@ct.gov
Department: Office of Policy and Management

Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH)
Email: dph.foi@ct.gov

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Sincerely,

DAVID MEDEIROS

communications.subject: RE: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request #OPM ID # 24-85
communications.communication:
To: OPM.FOI@ct.gov
Subject: Re: FOIA Requests #24-81 and #24-84 – Request for Accommodations and Accessibility Provisions

Dear FOIA Officers,

Thank you for acknowledging FOIA requests OPM ID #24-81 and OPM ID #24-84. To ensure I can fully access and engage with all responses, I respectfully request adherence to the following accommodations, which are essential for my full participation:

Accommodation Requests
1. Contact Requirement
All responses, updates, and communications must be sent exclusively via email to AabiWR@live.com. Do not use physical mail, phone calls, portal-based communications, external links, or any platform outside of direct email. This ensures clarity and accessibility.

2. Format Requirement
*** Please include the full text of each response within the body of the email, in addition to any attachments for download. This dual format is necessary for me to access information without obstruction and allows me to participate fully without complications.

3. Complete and Transparent Documentation
Provide all requested documents in full, with minimal redactions unless legally required. For any necessary redactions, please cite the specific legal exemption or statute applied, accompanied by a brief summary to facilitate understanding. This ensures that I have comprehensive access to all relevant information.

4. Detailed Explanations for Any Denials
If any portion of this request is denied, please provide a clear, detailed explanation for each denied item, citing the relevant legal statutes or exemptions. This clarity is essential for me to understand any limitations on access.

5. Guidance for Complex Records
For records containing complex financial, legal, or medical language, please include summaries or simplified explanations to enhance comprehension. This accommodation ensures I can accurately interpret and fully understand the information provided.

6. Identification of FOIA Officer Handling This Request
*** Please provide the full name, title, and direct contact information of the FOIA officer(s) assigned to my request. Communication should remain email-only, but having this information supports transparency and record-keeping.

7. Confirmation of Accommodations
Confirm receipt of this request and explicitly acknowledge that each accommodation listed will be fully applied in all responses and communications.

Request for Expedited Processing
I reiterate my request for expedited processing due to the public interest and immediate impact on vulnerable Medicaid beneficiaries within Connecticut’s ABI Waiver Program.

Thank you for your attention to these details, which ensure transparency, accessibility, and equitable engagement in this process. I look forward to receiving confirmation and further updates on these requests.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources
Email: AabiWR@live.com
Address: 215 Mountain Street, Willimantic, CT 06226

communications.subject: RE: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request #OPM ID # 24-85
communications.communication:
Comprehensive Appeal for FOIA Requests OPM ID #24-81 and OPM ID #24-84
From: David Medeiros
Date: November 20, 2024
To: Office of Policy and Management (OPM)
CC: Listed State and Federal Agencies and Department Heads

Subject: Appeal for Legal and Constitutional Compliance with FOIA Requests OPM ID #24-81 and OPM ID #24-84 and Enforcement of ADA Accommodations
Introduction
This appeal addresses significant deficiencies in the responses to FOIA requests OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84 regarding records for the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. As a Medicaid recipient and an advocate for individuals with disabilities, I rely on the transparency mandated by state and federal FOIA laws to ensure accountability and equitable program administration. This appeal also highlights persistent violations of statutory ADA accommodation requirements and constitutional protections.

Summary of FOIA Requests
I requested:

Legislative Records:
Bills, amendments, legislative history, and meeting minutes related to the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Public Records:
Financial statements, budget allocations, program assessments, contracts, and audits pursuant to Connecticut’s transparency statutes (C.G.S. § 4-66).
Correspondence:
Internal and external communication, directives, memoranda, and policies regarding the ABI Waiver Program.
Personnel Records:
Non-confidential job descriptions, resumes, performance evaluations, and organizational charts related to program oversight and administration.
Program Information:
Procedural documents, compliance reviews, demographic data, and performance outcomes required under federal CMS regulations (42 CFR § 440.180).
Purpose:
To ensure compliance, transparency, and equitable administration of taxpayer-funded services critical to individuals with acquired brain injuries.

Legal Framework and Basis for Appeal
Federal and State FOIA Compliance
Federal FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552):
Guarantees access to federal records, mandates timely responses, and requires detailed explanations for delays or denials.
Connecticut FOIA (C.G.S. §§ 1-200 to 1-242):
Ensures access to state-held records within four business days and prohibits unnecessary delays or redactions.
Medicaid Statute (42 U.S.C. § 1396 et seq.):
Mandates accountability in Medicaid programs, including state compliance with CMS requirements.
Executive Order 13392:
Directs agencies to improve FOIA processing and transparency.
ADA and Section 504 Compliance
ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.):
Prohibits discrimination and requires public entities to provide reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794):
Guarantees equal access to federally funded programs and public records.
Violations and Deficiencies
1. Non-Compliance with FOIA Timelines
Connecticut Law (C.G.S. § 1-210):
Requires confirmation of receipt and timeline estimates within four business days. OPM acknowledged receipt but failed to provide specific timelines for document production or updates on progress.
Federal FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)):
Mandates prompt responses and proactive communication regarding delays. These requirements have not been met.
2. Inadequate Acknowledgment of ADA Accommodations
My request explicitly outlined Non-Negotiable ADA Accommodations, which were ignored:
Email-only communication.
Screen-reader-compatible PDF attachments.
Simplified summaries for complex records.
Identification of responsible FOIA personnel.
Expedited processing under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E).
Failure to implement these accommodations violates both ADA Title II and Section 504, depriving me of equal access to the FOIA process.

3. Unjustified Redactions and Potential Fee Assessments
Fee Waiver Denial:
The request meets public interest criteria under C.G.S. § 1-212(d) and 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). No statutory basis has been provided for proposed fees.
Failure to Justify Redactions:
Federal FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)) requires detailed explanations for exemptions, including statutory citations. These justifications have not been provided.
Non-Negotiable ADA Accommodations (Updated)
MuckRock Platform Only:

All responses must be sent through the MuckRock platform to ensure accessibility and compliance.
Direct Text in Email Body:

Full text of responses embedded in the email body to enhance readability and accessibility.
Screen-Reader-Compatible PDFs:

Clearly labeled, properly formatted PDFs must accompany email responses.
Simplified Summaries:

Provide simplified explanations for technical, financial, or legal documents.
Identification of Responsible Personnel:

Full names, titles, and contact information for FOIA officers and supervisory personnel.
Detailed Justifications for Denials:

Cite specific exemptions for any withheld or redacted information.
Expedited Processing:

Requests must be processed urgently, as mandated under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E) and Executive Order 13392.
Constitutional Violations
1. First Amendment (Right to Petition the Government)
The refusal to provide timely and accessible information infringes upon my constitutional right to petition for redress of grievances.

2. Fourteenth Amendment (Equal Protection Clause)
Denial of ADA accommodations constitutes unequal treatment of individuals with disabilities, violating federal law and constitutional protections.

3. Fifth Amendment (Due Process Clause)
The lack of transparency, failure to justify delays, and insufficient responses deprive me of my right to procedural due process.

4. Supremacy Clause (Article VI, Clause 2)
State practices inconsistent with federal FOIA and ADA standards violate the Supremacy Clause, which establishes the primacy of federal law.

Requested Actions
Full Compliance with FOIA Requests OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84:

Provide all responsive documents promptly and in adherence to the updated accommodations.
Confirmation of Accommodations:

Explicit acknowledgment that all updated accommodations will be applied moving forward.
Justifications for Redactions and Fees:

Provide detailed statutory justifications for any redactions or fees.
Timeline for Completion:

Submit a clear and reasonable timeline for fulfilling these requests.
CC List for Transparency and Accountability
State of Connecticut Agencies:

Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS): Dr. Deidre S. Gifford (foia.dss@ct.gov)
Connecticut Office of the Attorney General: William Tong (attorney.general@ct.gov)
Connecticut General Assembly (CGA): Senator Martin M. Looney (foia@cga.ct.gov)
Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM): Melissa McCaw (opm.foia@ct.gov)
Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH): Dr. Manisha Juthani (dph.foi@ct.gov)
Federal Agencies:

HHS: Xavier Becerra (HHS_FOIA@hhs.gov)
CMS: Chiquita Brooks-LaSure (FOIA_Request@cms.hhs.gov)
DOJ: Merrick B. Garland (foia.requests@usdoj.gov)
HUD: Marcia L. Fudge (foiarequests@hud.gov)
DOL: Julie Su (foiarequests@dol.gov)
FTC: Alvaro M. Bedoya (FOIA@ftc.gov)
Conclusion
Failure to address these violations and implement the requested actions will result in escalation to oversight bodies, including state and federal courts. Compliance with FOIA and ADA obligations is not optional and ensures equitable access for all citizens.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources
Email: AabiWR@live.com
Address: 215 Mountain Street, Willimantic, CT 06226

communications.subject: RE: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request #OPM ID # 24-85
communications.communication:
Subject: Appeal for Legal and Constitutional Compliance with FOIA Requests OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84

Date: December 10, 2024

To: Office of Policy and Management (OPM) FOIA Appeals Officer

CC:

Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS)
Connecticut Office of the Attorney General
Connecticut General Assembly (CGA)
Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM)
Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH)
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)
U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ)
Relevant Congressional Oversight Committees
Dear FOIA Appeals Officer,

This appeal addresses significant deficiencies in the responses to FOIA requests OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84 regarding records for the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. These deficiencies include violations of the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and constitutional protections. Immediate corrective actions are required to uphold statutory and constitutional obligations.

Key Issues
Non-Compliance with FOIA Obligations

FOIA requires timely responses, transparency, and justification for denials (5 U.S.C. § 552, Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210). Neither request has been fulfilled, nor has a timeline been provided for completion.
Failure to Provide ADA Accommodations

My explicit ADA accommodation requests, including email-only communication, screen-reader-compatible documents, and simplified summaries, have not been honored, violating ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.) and Section 504 (29 U.S.C. § 794).
Lack of Accountability

Your office has not identified the FOIA officers or decision-makers responsible for processing these requests, contrary to transparency mandates.
Potential Constitutional Violations

Failure to comply with ADA and FOIA constitutes a violation of my First Amendment right to petition the government, my Fourteenth Amendment right to equal protection, and my Fifth Amendment right to due process.
Updated and Specific Relief Sought
Immediate Full Compliance

Provide all requested records, including legislative, financial, correspondence, personnel, and program documentation.
Ensure compliance with FOIA timelines by submitting all records or updates within five (5) business days.
Implementation of ADA Accommodations

Route all communications exclusively through the MuckRock platform, as required for accessibility.
Provide all records as screen-reader-compatible PDFs, properly labeled and indexed.
Include simplified summaries for complex financial, legal, or medical records.
Accountability Measures

Identify FOIA officers and decision-makers, including their names, titles, and contact information.
Provide detailed justifications for any redactions or denials, citing applicable statutory exemptions.
Expedited Processing and Fee Waiver

Confirm expedited processing under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E) due to the public interest and impact on vulnerable Medicaid beneficiaries.
Reaffirm my fee waiver request as this request is non-commercial and in the public interest.
Detailed Timeline for Completion

Submit a clear and specific timeline for the production of all responsive records.
Legal Framework Supporting This Appeal
FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552 and Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210)

Requires timely, transparent responses and prohibits unnecessary delays.
ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.) and Section 504 (29 U.S.C. § 794)

Mandate reasonable accommodations for individuals with disabilities, ensuring equitable access to public records.
First Amendment

Protects the right to petition the government for redress of grievances, including access to information.
Fourteenth Amendment

Guarantees equal protection under the law, which includes equal access to public services for individuals with disabilities.
Fifth Amendment

Ensures due process rights, which are infringed by delayed or inaccessible responses.
Consequences of Continued Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with statutory and constitutional obligations will result in the following:

Administrative Complaints

Complaints will be filed with the Connecticut Freedom of Information Commission, the U.S. Department of Justice Civil Rights Division, and the Office for Civil Rights.
Judicial Action

Legal remedies will be pursued under FOIA, ADA, and constitutional protections to enforce compliance.
Public Reporting

Non-compliance will be reported to media outlets, advocacy organizations, and oversight committees to ensure public accountability.
Conclusion
This appeal is an opportunity for your office to rectify systemic failures and demonstrate a commitment to transparency, accountability, and accessibility. I expect a full response and compliance with the relief sought by December 17, 2024.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources
39 Kings HWY STE C
Gales Ferry, CT 06335

communications.subject: RE: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request #OPM ID # 24-85
communications.communication:
Subject: Final Assertion of Legal Obligations Under FOIA, ADA, and Constitutional Law
Subject: 10/17/2024 Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program Records (Office Of Policy And Management)

01.08.2025

To all It May Concern in All Relevant Departments and Divisions,

Office Of Policy And Management
Office of Legal Affairs Office of Policy and Management
450 Capitol Avenue MS# 55 SEC Hartford, CT 06106-1379 OPM.FOI@ct.gov

This correspondence pertains to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. Your handling of this matter raises critical concerns under FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12132), and constitutional principles of government accountability.

As recognized in National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004), transparency is fundamental to democracy and public trust. Your agency’s obligations are not discretionary, and failure to meet them constitutes a violation of statutory and constitutional law. This letter establishes your duties, addresses deficiencies, and anticipates and counters all potential deflection strategies.

1. FOIA Obligations: Statutory Mandates and Required Actions
FOIA establishes an enforceable right of access to federal agency records. Your response must meet the following requirements:

A. Timeliness
Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A), you are required to provide a determination within 20 business days. Delays beyond this timeframe, absent legitimate extension requests, constitute a violation of FOIA.

Countermeasure: Delays are actionable under Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. DOJ, 711 F.3d 180 (D.C. Cir. 2013).
Required Action: Provide the requested records or a lawful determination.

B. Adequacy of Search
FOIA requires a thorough and reasonable search for records, as established in Campbell v. DOJ, 164 F.3d 20 (D.C. Cir. 1998). This includes:

Identifying the databases, locations, and terms used.
Providing a sworn affidavit detailing the search scope.
Countermeasure: A vague claim of "no responsive records" is insufficient without a detailed affidavit.
Required Action: Submit a sworn affidavit documenting the search or confirm the existence of responsive records.

C. Proper Use of Exemptions
Exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b) must be narrowly applied and justified with specific explanations. Blanket or vague exemptions are impermissible.

Countermeasure: A Vaughn index (Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973)) is required to justify each withholding.
Required Action: Submit a Vaughn index detailing each exemption and its justification within 10 business days.

D. Decentralization and Referrals
Referrals or decentralization excuses do not absolve your agency of its responsibility to provide a consolidated response. As held in McGehee v. CIA, 697 F.2d 1095 (D.C. Cir. 1983), agencies must coordinate internally to ensure compliance.

Countermeasure: Require assurance of continuity and coordination across divisions.
Required Action: Consolidate records from all relevant offices and provide a unified response.

2. ADA and Rehabilitation Act Compliance: Equal Access as a Legal Right
As a person with a documented disability, I am entitled to reasonable accommodations under the ADA and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Your failure to provide accessible formats for requested records constitutes discrimination and violates federal law.

Case Law:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004): Agencies must ensure meaningful access to government services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985): Denial of reasonable accommodations creates barriers that violate civil rights.
Required Action:

Provide all requested records in accessible formats, including plain-language summaries or electronic files compatible with assistive technologies.
Confirm compliance with ADA requirements by [specific date].
3. Mandated Reporting and Whistleblower Protections
Your handling of this request implicates broader concerns, including potential fraud, misuse of federal funds, or retaliation against whistleblowers. Under the Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302), you are required to report and address systemic violations.

Countermeasure: Reference Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4), which requires the reporting of observed violations of law.
Required Action: Document and escalate evidence of misconduct to oversight bodies, including the Office of Inspector General (OIG).

4. Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with your statutory obligations knowingly constitutes violations of:

Obstruction of Justice (18 U.S.C. § 1505): Delaying lawful access to records obstructs public accountability.
Civil Rights Violations (42 U.S.C. § 1983): Denying ADA accommodations constitutes a deprivation of federally protected rights.
Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4): Concealing or failing to report observed violations is a criminal act.
Countermeasure: Prepare for judicial review, oversight complaints, and public advocacy if compliance fails.
5. Escalation Pathways
If your office does not comply within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this matter through:

Judicial Review: Filing a lawsuit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel disclosure.
Oversight Complaints: Submitting formal complaints to OGIS, OIG, and the DOJ Civil Rights Division.
Public Advocacy: Engaging investigative journalists, transparency advocates, and public interest organizations to ensure accountability.

6. Final Statement: Upholding Transparency and Accountability
This matter reflects the public’s right to transparency and the preservation of trust in government institutions. Your actions will either affirm your agency’s commitment to accountability or further evidence systemic disregard for these principles.

I look forward to your prompt and substantive response.

David Medeiros
ABI Resources

Summary of Responsibilities
Each individual and organization listed plays a crucial role in federal and state oversight, advocacy, and the protection of civil rights. Their functions include but are not limited to:

Oversight & Accountability: Ensuring compliance with federal and state laws, including Medicaid regulations, FOIA, ADA, and civil rights protections.
Transparency & Advocacy: Promoting open government practices and supporting whistleblower activities.
Civil Rights Enforcement: Addressing violations of constitutional and statutory protections against discrimination.
Legislative Oversight: Monitoring government programs and expenditures, particularly those impacting vulnerable populations like Medicaid beneficiaries.
Judicial and Administrative Review: Offering remedies for non-compliance through litigation or administrative actions.
