ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.
Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication

All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.
Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.
Identification of Responsible Officers

Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.
Non-Negotiable Compliance

These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

The challenges we face today demand more than acknowledgment—they require action, collaboration, and a unified commitment to solutions. Together, we must embrace transparency, accountability, and compassion as the foundation of our efforts. By fostering open communication, prioritizing the needs of the most vulnerable, and holding systems accountable, we can rebuild trust and ensure equitable outcomes for all.

Solutions lie in unity—when state and federal leaders, advocates, and communities work hand in hand to uphold justice and fairness. Transparency through accessible Freedom of Information processes, adherence to legal mandates, and robust oversight are the pillars that support meaningful change. Each of us has a role to play in creating a system that serves and protects.

Our collective mission is clear: to build bridges between agencies and communities, ensure the dignity of every individual, and honor the principles that guide us toward progress. Together, with determination and unity, we can overcome systemic failures and pave the way for a brighter, more inclusive future.

communications.subject: RE: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request #OPM ID # 24-84
communications.communication:
Appeal for FOIA Requests OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84

To: ***** Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.
Office of Policy and Management (OPM) FOIA Appeals Officer
450 Capitol Avenue, MS# 55 SEC
Hartford, CT 06106-1379
Email: OPM.FOI@ct.gov

Subject: Appeal for Incomplete Response to FOIA Requests OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84

Date: January 9, 2025
From: David Medeiros
ABI Resources

Introduction
This appeal addresses deficiencies in the response to FOIA requests OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84 regarding the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. The documents provided fail to satisfy the scope of my request and do not comply with state and federal Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) obligations, as well as statutory ADA accommodation requirements.

Grounds for Appeal
1. Failure to Provide Complete Records
The records provided are insufficient and omit critical components of the request, including:

Legislative Records: Bills, amendments, resolutions, legislative history, and voting records on the ABI Waiver Program were not included.

Public Records: Missing comprehensive financial records, including budget allocations, financial statements, and audits, required for program transparency.

Correspondence: Internal and external communications, including emails and directives related to the program, were not provided.

Personnel Records: Non-confidential employment records and organizational charts related to program administration were excluded.

Program Information: Enrollment data, performance metrics, and compliance reviews were not included.

2. Failure to Provide Justifications for Redactions or Denials
The response lacks a Vaughn Index or detailed justifications for any omissions or redactions, as required by FOIA statutes (Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210 and 5 U.S.C. § 552(b)).

3. ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.

Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication
All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the  body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.
Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.
Identification of Responsible Officers

***** Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request. ****

Non-Negotiable Compliance

These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

Relief Requested
To address the above deficiencies, I formally request the following actions:

1. Complete Records Production
Provide all requested records, including:

Legislative history, voting records, and meeting minutes related to the ABI Waiver Program.
Comprehensive public records, including budget allocations, audits, and financial data.
Correspondence between the Department of Social Services (DSS), OPM, and external entities related to the program.
Personnel records, job descriptions, and organizational charts for staff overseeing the program.
Program information such as enrollment data, compliance reviews, and outcome reports.

2. Detailed Justifications for Redactions or Denials
Submit a Vaughn Index or equivalent documentation detailing statutory exemptions for withheld or redacted records.

3. ADA Compliance
Immediately comply with ADA accommodations, including:

ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.
Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication

All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.
Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.
Identification of Responsible Officers

Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.

Non-Negotiable Compliance
These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

4. Timeline for Completion
Provide a clear timeline for fulfilling this appeal and any pending records requests.

Legal Basis
FOIA Compliance (Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210, 5 U.S.C. § 552)
The FOIA mandates timely, complete responses to public records requests. Any delays or incomplete responses must be accompanied by statutory justifications.

ADA Compliance (42 U.S.C. § 12132, 29 U.S.C. § 794)
Public entities are required to provide reasonable accommodations to ensure equitable access to information for individuals with disabilities.

Constitutional Protections
Failure to comply with FOIA and ADA violates:

First Amendment: Right to petition the government for redress of grievances.
Fourteenth Amendment: Equal protection under the law.
Fifth Amendment: Due process rights.
Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to resolve this matter will result in escalation through the following avenues:

Administrative Complaints: Filing with the Connecticut Freedom of Information Commission and the Department of Justice Civil Rights Division.
Judicial Remedies: Pursuing litigation to compel compliance with FOIA and ADA obligations.
Public Advocacy: Engaging transparency organizations and media outlets to highlight systemic non-compliance.
Conclusion
This appeal serves as an opportunity for OPM to correct these deficiencies and demonstrate a commitment to transparency, accountability, and accessibility. I expect a response within ten (10) business days outlining your corrective actions.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

Attachments:

Original FOIA Requests (OPM ID #24-81 and #24-84)
Documents Provided by OPM
CC:

Connecticut Freedom of Information Commission
U.S. Department of Justice Civil Rights Division
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)
Office of Government Information Services (OGIS)

01/21/2025

Request for Assistance – Medicaid Oversight, ADA Compliance, Retaliation, and Civil Rights

Dear Senator Richard Blumenthal, Senator Chris Murphy, Governor Ned Lamont, and Attorney General William Tong,

I am reaching out to request your support in addressing urgent concerns related to Medicaid oversight, ADA compliance failures, whistleblower retaliation, and civil rights violations within the State of Connecticut. As leaders committed to justice and equity, your intervention is critical to ensuring transparency, accountability, and the protection of vulnerable individuals who rely on federally funded programs.

These systemic issues not only harm individuals but also undermine public trust in programs designed to serve our most vulnerable populations. I respectfully ask for your assistance in holding HHS, CMS, DOJ, FBI, DSS, CHRO, and other relevant agencies accountable for their responsibilities under federal and state law.

Your leadership and dedication to justice are invaluable in advancing these efforts. Please let me know how I can provide further information or collaborate to address these critical issues.

01/21/2025

Final Assertion of Legal Obligations Under FOIA, ADA, and Constitutional Law

Subject: 12/23/2024 Freedom of Information Act Request: OSC Cases DI-25-000310, DI-25-000325, DI-25-000379, DI-12192024714, and DI-12112024134; Associated FBI, DOJ, HHS, CMS, OAG, OIP , DOT and Medicaid Oversight

Records FOIA (Federal Bureau of Investigation)

To: ALL

Deborah Waller

(202) 616-0646

NW Washington, DC 20530

*** Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)
Subject: Urgent Request for Investigation into OSC Case Records, Altered Decisions, and Suppressed Reports

Dear FBI Team,

I am formally requesting your assistance to investigate systemic failures, misconduct, and potential criminal activity surrounding the handling of my submissions to the Office of Special Counsel (OSC). These failures directly impact whistleblower protections, Medicaid oversight, and public accountability.

Issues to Investigate

1. Case Numbers and Records Management

Case Numbers Requiring Investigation:

DI-25-000310

DI-25-000325

DI-25-000379

DI-12192024714

DI-12112024134

OSCFiling-MedeirosDavid-DI-12112024134

OSCFiling-MedeirosDavid-DI-12202024300

OSCFiling-MedeirosDavid-DI-112620241121

2. Anonymity and Lack of Accountability in Decision-Making

Unsigned Determination Letters:

Many determination letters from OSC lack identifiable signatures, names, or clear authorship.

This practice raises serious concerns about accountability and compliance with transparency laws.

3. Suppressed or Altered Records

Evidence suggests discrepancies between the whistleblower reports I submitted and how they were recorded or handled by OSC.

Specific issues include:

Alterations or removal of content from submitted complaints.

Suppression of reports that exposed systemic failures in Medicaid oversight and retaliation against whistleblowers.

4. Lack of FOIA Compliance

Despite repeated Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests, OSC and related agencies have failed to provide:

Complete case files and communication logs.

Justification for withheld or redacted information.

Clear timelines for compliance.

Specific Questions to Investigate

1. Who is Responsible for Managing These Records?

Identify the individuals, teams, or automated systems involved in creating, altering, and assigning these case numbers and reports.

2. What Decisions Were Made and Why?

Determine how decisions were reached, why some reports were closed without action, and why letters were sent anonymously.

3. Were There Violations of Federal Law?

Investigate potential obstruction of justice, retaliation, or misuse of authority under whistleblower protection laws and FOIA.

Key Agencies and Officials Involved

This matter spans multiple federal and state agencies, including:

• Office of Special Counsel (OSC)

• Department of Justice (DOJ)

• Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)

• Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)

• Office of Inspector General (OIG)

Why This Matters

1. Whistleblower Protections:

Retaliation against whistleblowers and suppression of reports undermine federal protections designed to safeguard transparency and accountability.

2. Impact on Vulnerable Populations:

These failures harm Medicaid consumers, particularly those with disabilities, by allowing systemic mismanagement to persist unchecked.

3. Misuse of Taxpayer Funds:

Lack of oversight and accountability results in waste and misuse of federal funds meant to serve the public.

Requested Actions

1. Investigate Record Management:

Audit all OSC records, emails, and internal communications related to these case numbers.

Identify responsible individuals or systems.

2. Subpoena Additional Evidence:

Secure all suppressed or altered reports to ensure a complete and accurate investigation.

3. Hold Accountable Those Involved in Misconduct:

Recommend prosecution or disciplinary action for any individuals found to have violated federal laws.

4. Ensure Compliance with FOIA and Whistleblower Protections:

Mandate OSC and related agencies to comply fully with FOIA requests and whistleblower laws.

Attachments

I have attached all available documentation, including:

Correspondence with OSC, including determination letters and emails.

FOIA requests and responses (or lack thereof).

Detailed reports submitted to OSC and other federal agencies.

This issue demands immediate attention to uphold the principles of transparency, accountability, and justice. I am available to provide additional information or documentation as needed.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

Subject: 12/23/2024 Freedom of Information Act Request: OSC Cases DI-25-000310, DI-25-000325, DI-25-000379, DI-12192024714, and DI-12112024134; Associated FBI, DOJ, HHS, CMS, OAG, OIP , DOT and Medicaid Oversight Records FOIA (Federal Bureau of Investigation)

This correspondence pertains to my Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. Your handling of this matter raises critical concerns under FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12132), and constitutional principles of government accountability.

OSC Case Records

Complete files, internal and external communications, investigations, and resolutions regarding:

OSCFiling-MedeirosDavid-DI-11252024342 .pdf

OSCFiling-MedeirosDavid-DI-11272024158 .pdf

OSCFiling-MedeirosDavid-DI-11282024737 .pdf

OSCFiling-MedeirosDavid-DI-112620241121 .pdf

OSC File No. DI-25-000379

DI-25-000310

DI-25-000325

DI-25-000379

DI-12192024714

DI-12112024134

As recognized in National Archives and Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004), transparency is fundamental to democracy and public trust. Your agency’s obligations are not discretionary, and failure to meet them constitutes a violation of statutory and constitutional law. This letter establishes your duties, addresses deficiencies, and anticipates and counters all potential deflection strategies.

1. FOIA Obligations: Statutory Mandates and Required Actions
FOIA establishes an enforceable right of access to federal agency records. Your response must meet the following requirements:

A. Timeliness
Under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A), you are required to provide a determination within 20 business days. Delays beyond this timeframe, absent legitimate extension requests, constitute a violation of FOIA.
Countermeasure: Delays are actionable under Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. DOJ, 711 F.3d 180 (D.C. Cir. 2013).
Required Action: Provide the requested records or a lawful determination.

B. Adequacy of Search
FOIA requires a thorough and reasonable search for records, as established in Campbell v. DOJ, 164 F.3d 20 (D.C. Cir. 1998). This includes:
Identifying the databases, locations, and terms used.
Providing a sworn affidavit detailing the search scope.
Countermeasure: A vague claim of "no responsive records" is insufficient without a detailed affidavit.
Required Action: Submit a sworn affidavit documenting the search or confirm the existence of responsive records.

C. Proper Use of Exemptions
Exemptions under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b) must be narrowly applied and justified with specific explanations. Blanket or vague exemptions are impermissible.
Countermeasure: A Vaughn index (Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973)) is required to justify each withholding.
Required Action: Submit a Vaughn index detailing each exemption and its justification within 10 business days.

D. Decentralization and Referrals
Referrals or decentralization excuses do not absolve your agency of its responsibility to provide a consolidated response. As held in McGehee v. CIA, 697 F.2d 1095 (D.C. Cir. 1983), agencies must coordinate internally to ensure compliance.
Countermeasure: Require assurance of continuity and coordination across divisions.
Required Action: Consolidate records from all relevant offices and provide a unified response.

2. ADA and Rehabilitation Act Compliance: Equal Access as a Legal Right
As a person with a documented disability, I am entitled to reasonable accommodations under the ADA and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. Your failure to provide accessible formats for requested records constitutes discrimination and violates federal law.

Case Law:
Tennessee v. Lane, 541 U.S. 509 (2004): Agencies must ensure meaningful access to government services.
Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287 (1985): Denial of reasonable accommodations creates barriers that violate civil rights.

Required Action:
Provide all requested records in accessible formats, including plain-language summaries or electronic files compatible with assistive technologies.
Confirm compliance with ADA requirements by [specific date].

3. Mandated Reporting and Whistleblower Protections
Your handling of this request implicates broader concerns, including potential fraud, misuse of federal funds, or retaliation against whistleblowers. Under the Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302), you are required to report and address systemic violations.
Countermeasure: Reference Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4), which requires the reporting of observed violations of law.
Required Action: Document and escalate evidence of misconduct to oversight bodies, including the Office of Inspector General (OIG).

4. Consequences of Non-Compliance
Failure to comply with your statutory obligations knowingly constitutes violations of:
Obstruction of Justice (18 U.S.C. § 1505): Delaying lawful access to records obstructs public accountability.
Civil Rights Violations (42 U.S.C. § 1983): Denying ADA accommodations constitutes a deprivation of federally protected rights.
Misprision of Felony (18 U.S.C. § 4): Concealing or failing to report observed violations is a criminal act.
Countermeasure: Prepare for judicial review, oversight complaints, and public advocacy if compliance fails.

5. Escalation Pathways
If your office does not comply within the specified timeframe, I will escalate this matter through:
Judicial Review: Filing a lawsuit under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(B) to compel disclosure.
Oversight Complaints: Submitting formal complaints to OGIS, OIG, and the DOJ Civil Rights Division.
Public Advocacy: Engaging investigative journalists, transparency advocates, and public interest organizations to ensure accountability.

6. Final Statement: Upholding Transparency and Accountability
This matter reflects the public’s right to transparency and the preservation of trust in government institutions. Your actions will either affirm your agency’s commitment to accountability or further evidence systemic disregard for these principles.

I look forward to your prompt and substantive response.

David Medeiros
ABI Resources

Summary of Responsibilities

Each individual and organization listed plays a crucial role in federal and state oversight, advocacy, and the protection of civil rights. Their functions include but are not limited to:

Oversight & Accountability: Ensuring compliance with federal and state laws, including Medicaid regulations, FOIA, ADA, and civil rights protections.

Transparency & Advocacy: Promoting open government practices and supporting whistleblower activities.

Civil Rights Enforcement: Addressing violations of constitutional and statutory protections against discrimination.

Legislative Oversight: Monitoring government programs and expenditures, particularly those impacting vulnerable populations like Medicaid beneficiaries.

Judicial and Administrative Review: Offering remedies for non-compliance through litigation or administrative actions.

ADA Accommodations Request

This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132)

and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations

To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.

Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.

Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication

All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.

Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.

Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.

Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.

Identification of Responsible Officers

Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.

Non-Negotiable Compliance

These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank
you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

________________________________________________

ANF:AKL
25-00146-F

Dear Mr. Medeiros:

This is in further response to your December 26, 2024, Freedom of Information Act
request, received by the Civil Rights Division, seeking access to records pertaining to:

1. OSC Case Records Complete files, internal and external communications,
investigations, and resolutions regarding: DI-25-000310; DI-25-000325; DI-25-
000379; DI-12192024714; DI-12112024134.

2. Interagency Correspondence Communications between OSC, FBI, DOJ, CMS,
HHS, and relevant state agencies regarding: Whistleblower disclosures and
investigations. Enforcement of ADA, Medicaid transparency, and constitutional
compliance. Allegations or investigations into fraud, retaliation, and procedural
violations.

3. FBI Involvement Documentation reflecting FBI’s role in addressing OSC-related
investigations, whistleblower protections, and Medicaid; compliance. Include:
Correspondence with OSC, DOJ, CMS and HHS regarding whistleblower
allegations. Investigative records and findings.

4. DOJ and HHS Oversight DOJ Civil Rights Division and HHS OCR records
related to: ADA compliance investigations. Complaints and procedural
documentation under OCR Transaction Number 01-25-592844. Federal and state
enforcement actions against systemic non-compliance.

5. CMS and Medicaid Audits All internal and external audits, investigations, and
compliance reviews associated with the Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI)
Waiver Program. Documents relating to whistleblower-reported fraud, misuse of
funds, and oversight deficiencies.
Freedom of Information/PA Unit –4CON
950 Pennsylvania Ave., NW
Washington, DC 20530

6. FOIA Compliance Records Metadata, processing logs, and communications
related to this FOIA request, including: Identified responsible officers and internal

procedural reviews.

After a thorough search, I have determined that the Civil Rights Division has no records
pertaining your request.

If you are not satisfied with the Civil Rights Division’s determination in response to this
request, you may administratively appeal by writing to the Director, Office of Information Policy
(OIP), United States Department of Justice, 441 G Street, NW, 6th Floor, Washington, D.C.
20530, or you may submit an appeal through OIP's FOIA STAR portal by creating an account on
the following website: https://www.justice.gov/oip/submit-and-track-request-or-appeal. Your
appeal must be postmarked or electronically transmitted within 90 days of the date of my
response to your request. If you submit your appeal by mail, both the letter and the envelope
should be clearly marked "Freedom of Information Act Appeal."
Additionally, you may contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at
the National Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIA mediation services
they offer. The contact information for OGIS is: Office of Government Information Services,
National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park,
Maryland 20740-6001; e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-
684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. Please reference the FOIA/PA No. above in any
correspondence with OGIS.
I hope the Civil Rights Division has been of some assistance to you in this matter.

Sincerely,

April N. Freeman
April Freeman, FOIA Liaison
Freedom of Information/Privacy Acts Unit
Civil Rights Division

_____________________________________________________________________________________

The challenges we face today demand more than acknowledgment—they require action, collaboration, and a unified commitment to solutions. Together, we must embrace transparency, accountability, and compassion as the
foundation of our efforts. By fostering open communication, prioritizing the needs of the most vulnerable, and holding systems accountable, we can rebuild trust and ensure equitable outcomes for all.

Solutions lie in unity—when state and federal leaders, advocates, and communities work hand in hand to uphold justice and fairness. Transparency through accessible Freedom of Information processes, adherence to legal
mandates, and robust oversight are the pillars that support meaningful change. Each of us has a role to play in creating a system that serves and protects.

Our collective mission is clear: to build bridges between agencies and communities, ensure the dignity of every individual, and honor the principles that guide us toward progress. Together, with determination and unity, we can
overcome systemic failures and pave the way for a brighter, more inclusive future.

Americans living with disabilities and their families are Americans—full citizens of this nation, protected by the same Constitution that guarantees the rights and freedoms of every individual. We are not separate, lesser, or forgotten. We are Americans with the same unalienable rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.

We stand firmly on the principles of equality, dignity, and justice. Our voices matter. Our contributions matter. And our rights—our Constitutional rights—must be respected, upheld, and protected without exception or delay.

We are Americans with rights. Period.

David Medeiros

https://www.archives.gov/founding-docs

CC:

Leo Terrell
Department of Justice (DOJ)

Pam Bondi, Attorney General of the United States
Assistant Attorney General, Civil Rights Division
Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)

Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Secretary of Health and Human Services
Deputy Secretary of HHS
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)

Dr. Mehmet Oz, Administrator
Chief Medical Officer
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Hedge Fund Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

You kindly sent us copies of your records that show information as listed below dated to June 30 2024. Please will it be possible to have an update on any records that would show some or all of the following information:
1. A list of ALL hedge funds and fund of hedge funds in which Richmond Retirement System is an investor; and
2. For each hedge fund and fund of hedge funds, may I please have a copy of any records that would show some or all of the following information:
a. the month by month market value of Richmond Retirement System's holding in each fund from July 1 2024 to September 30 2024
b. the month by month amount invested by Richmond Retirement System in each fund from July 1 2024 to September 30 2024
c. the month by month net returns (net of fees) earned by Richmond Retirement System on its investment in each fund from July 1 2024 to September 30 2024

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Haley Parker.

title: Vehicle registration records for license plate 43440U from 1970-1983

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Vehicle registration records for license plate 43440U from 1970-1983
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

Vehicle registration records from July 1, 1970 (or whatever date the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation started registering vehicles with state license plates, if later than July 1, 1970) until January 1, 1983, for tag number: 43440U

I need the records of the vehicle with license plate 43440U in Pennsylvania because I need to establish to whom the vehicle was registered through the year 1982. Such records should include the vehicle description, the name(s) of the owner of the vehicle, the registration plate number, and any addresses associated with the owner(s) of the vehicle.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Making an Exoneree

title: Noel Ignatin File Request (Federal Bureau of Investigation)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Noel Ignatin File Request (Federal Bureau of Investigation)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I request disclosure of any records that were prepared, received, transmitted, collected and/or maintained by the FBI, the Chicago Police Department, the Philadelphia Police Department, and the Gary, IN Police Department relating to Noel Ignatin. and the Provisional Organizing Committeee Marxist-Leninist. 

I.	I also request disclosure of any files or records that were received, transmitted, collected, and/or maintained by the FBI on an organization titled Provisional Organizing Committee (Marxist-Leninist), or “P.O.C”/”POC”, with the time frame of 1958 to 1966. 
II.	I also request disclosure of any files or records that were received, transmitted, collected, and/or maintained by the FBI on an organization titled Sojourner Truth Organization, with the time frame of 1969 to 1985. 

I am Maks Bondarenko, an individual seeking information affiliated with the educational institution of the CUNY Graduate Center’s Biography and Memoir Master of Arts program, and this request is made for scholarly purposes, not for commercial use. As I am making a request for scholarly purposes, I am entitled to a waiver of fees on behalf of the CUNY Graduate Center and its Biography and Memoir Master of Arts program.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Maks Bondarenko

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Military Service Record
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A releasable copy of the Official Military Personnel File of Joseph "Joe" Patrick Quinn, date of birth March 14, 1980, which should include: Name, Service Number, Dates of Service, Branch of Service, Final Duty Status, Final Rank, Assignments and Geographical locations, Military Education Level, Awards and Decorations, Photograph, Transcripts of Courts-Martial Trial, and place of entrance and separation

I would also like a releasable copy of his Official Personnel Folder which should include: past and present positions, past and present titles, past and present salaries, past and present grades, past and present job locations

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

George Johnston
An acknowledgement letter, stating the request is being processed.

communications.subject: Re: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Military Service Record
communications.communication:
This mailbox is not monitored, please do not reply. The information below is provided by auto-reply.

If you are having difficulty accessing your response document(s), please try the basic troubleshooting tips below:

- Password: Enter your request number (including the dash symbol).

- Unable to locate documents: Enter the information EXACTLY as it was provided in the original request. A ZIP code OR phone number (last four) is required.  Use the ZIP code OR phone number provided in the original request; otherwise, your response will not be located.  

- 30-day expiration: For security reasons, response documents are not accessible after 30 days and a new request will need to be submitted. Requests may be created using our online ordering system at: https://vetrecs.archives.gov/VeteranRequest/home.html

- No computer/laptop/printer: Suggest using resources (public library, family/friends, etc.) to access the eDelivery portal and download your documents. The eDelivery portal is also accessible via your mobile device. Be sure to fully remove downloaded documents from non-personal devices.

If you have already tried the tips outlined above and still require assistance, contact our Customer Service Team at (314) 801-0800 and have your request information available.

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (February 2025) (Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

title: Washington State Office of Administrative Hearings - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Washington State Office of Administrative Hearings - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
communications.communication:
January 12, 2025

via email to PublicRecords@oah.wa.gov

Washington State Office of Administrative Hearings - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
 
To whom it may concern,

RCW 40.14.026(5)

“To improve best practices for dissemination of public records, each agency with actual staff and legal costs associated with fulfilling public records requests of at least one hundred thousand dollars during the prior fiscal year must… report to the joint legislative audit and review committee by July 1st of each subsequent year the following metrics, measured over the preceding year:

RCW 40.14.026(5)(l)

(l) The estimated costs incurred by the agency in fulfilling records requests, including costs for staff compensation and legal review, and a measure of the average cost per request;

RCW 40.14.026(5)(o)

(o) The costs incurred by the agency with managing and retaining records, including staff compensation and purchases of equipment, hardware, software, and services to manage and retain public records or otherwise assist in the fulfillment of public records requests;

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act [RCW 42.56] I hereby request the following records:

1. Please provide all "Public Records" (as defined by WAC 44-14-03001) detailing costs incurred by your agency in fulfilling records requests, including staff compensation, legal review, and any public records related litigation costs and/or legal settlements for the year 2024 and complete copies of all records request realted fee payments paid to your agency in 2024.

Responsive public records should include but are not limited to:

Supplies and services external services (e.g., printing services, large format printing) Mailing costs, supplies (CDs, DVDs, USB sticks, etc.) Staff compensation and benefit records, copies of payments of Public Records Fees Collected, Software licensing, public records portal and database software licensing and costs, purchases of equipment, hardware, software, and services to manage and retain public records or otherwise assist in the fulfillment of public records requests, professional services Agency staff costs, copies of billing for all Legal costs – including copies of all litigation Legal settlements related to public records requests litigation of any kind and copies of costs for staff time associated with invoicing and collection.

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in the numerical order requested by subject matter and year. The most recent public records should be produced first.

DEFINITION OF RECORDS AND WRITINGS

RECORDS AND WRITINGS as defined by RCW 42.56.010(4): any handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, photographing, and every other means of recording any form of communication or representation including, but not limited to, letters, words, pictures, sounds, or symbols, or combination thereof, and all papers, maps, magnetic or paper tapes, photographic films and prints, motion picture, film and video recordings, magnetic or punched cards, discs, drums, diskettes, sound recordings, and other documents including existing data compilations from which information may be obtained or translated.

PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY OF ELECTRONIC RECORDS

Please provide all records in their native electronic format. Please do not instead create new records by printing electronic files then scanning and printing the newly scanned prints.

The use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA or NEXTREQUEST) for communication and production of records in response to a public records request is optional for the requestor in the State of Washington. Respectfully we decline to use any 3rd party "portal" system, specifically GOVQA and NEXTREQUEST. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment, or via no password, no registration internet cloud-based download link.

Please do not direct or invite us to use, register for, or communicate with your agency via any 3rd party portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other commercial 3rd party records portal service.

Constructive Notice: Any and all communication(s) received on behalf of your agency in reference to this Public Records Request (RCW 42.45) from any unauthorized for-profit 3rd party company doing business outside the State of Washington will be the subject of a new public records request to your agency as to the origin and purpose of the communication as well as the identity of the sender of the communication.

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS SUBMITTED VIA EMAIL

RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Unless the records exist IN PAPER FORM ONLY, DO NOT instead create new records by printing native stored electronic files, then scanning and re-printing these newly scanned prints only to reproduce them in again in electronic production.

EMAIL RECORDS

Please provide any and all email records in NATIVE .pst electronic format.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION - FAMILY EDUCATIONAL RIGHTS AND PRIVACY ACT (FERPA)

Take caution with the broad application of redaction and withholding of identified public records claiming "global FERPA" exemptions. When an agency claims an exemption for an entire record or portion of one, it must inform the requestor of the statutory exemption and provide a brief explanation of how the exemption applies to the record or portion withheld. RCW 42.17.310(4)/42.56.210(3). The brief explanation should cite the statute the agency claims grant an exemption from disclosure. The brief explanation should provide enough information for a requestor to make a threshold determination of whether the claimed exemption is proper. Global, nonspecific claims of exemption such as "FERPA" are insufficient. One way to properly provide a brief explanation of the withheld record or redaction is for the agency to provide a withholding index. It identifies the type of record, its date and number of pages, and the author or recipient of the record (unless their identity is exempt). The withholding index should allow a requestor to make a threshold determination of whether the agency has properly invoked the exemption. There are several exceptions to the FERPA exemption and any agency silently withholding large swaths of public records citing "FERPA!" without providing the original identified record, properly redacted, or if withheld in its entirety, providing a record description and page count or record length, will be challenged in accordance with RCW 42.56.550 if a reasonably detailed withholding index or exemption log is not included.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request.

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Washington State Office of Administrative Hearings - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
communications.communication:
January 21, 2025

MuckRock News DEPT MR 179640
263 Huntington Ave
Boston MA 02115

Re: Public Records Request No. P001178-011325

Dear Requester,

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Washington State Office of Administrative Hearings - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
communications.communication:
February 4, 2025

MuckRock News DEPT MR 179640
263 Huntington Ave
Boston MA 02115

Re: Public Records Request No. P001178-011325

Dear Requester,

The Office of Administrative Hearings received your public records request on January 13, 2025. You requested:

“Please provide all "Public Records" (as defined by WAC 44-14-03001) detailing costs incurred by your agency in fulfilling records requests, including staff compensation, legal review, and any public records related litigation costs and/or legal settlements for the year 2024 and complete copies of all records request realted fee payments paid to your agency in 2024. Responsive public records should include but are not limited to:
Supplies and services external services (e.g., printing services, large format printing) Mailing costs, supplies (CDs, DVDs, USB sticks, etc.) Staff compensation and benefit records, copies of payments of Public Records Fees Collected, Software licensing, public records portal and database software licensing and costs, purchases of equipment, hardware, software, and services to manage and retain public records or otherwise assist in the fulfillment of public records requests, professional services Agency staff costs, copies of billing for all Legal costs – including copies of all litigation Legal settlements related to public records requests litigation of any kind and copies of costs for staff time associated with invoicing and collection.”

We do not have records responsive to the following portions of your request:

  *   Mailing costs, supplies (CDs, DVDs, USB sticks, etc.) – OAH did not incur supply costs associated with public records request processing in 2024.
  *   Legal review, and any public records related litigation costs and/or legal settlements for the year 2024 – OAH did not incur legal review or litigation/settlement costs related to public records in 2024.
  *   Complete copies of all records request related fee payments paid to your agency in 2024 – OAH did not collect fees for any public records requests in 2024.
  *   Benefit records - OAH does not maintain records showing benefit costs incurred for individual employees. Our payroll is processed by the Department of Enterprises Services’ Small Agency Support, who maintains these records. Our benefit rate of 33% is reported to the Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee on our annual public records report.


The records responsive to the remainder of your request are attached. This request is now closed. This means that OAH will not take any further action on your request. Any appeal about this request must be filed within one year of the date of this letter.[1]

If you have any questions, or believe I have closed your request in error, please contact me at PublicRecords@oah.wa.gov.

Sincerely,

Shannon Goudy
Information Governance Officer
Office of Administrative Hearings
​


[1] See RCW 42.56.550 for more information.

title: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2021) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2021

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2021) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2021
communications.communication:
SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2021) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2021

Via email: public.records@shorelineschools.org

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act [RCW 42.56] I hereby request the following records:

1.	I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2021 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2021.

Note: Parents and students seeking GRADES and/or TRANSCRIPTS in the year 2021 can be excluded from this request.

PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY OF ELECTRONIC RECORDS

The use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA or NEXTREQUEST) for communication and production of records in response to a public records request is optional for the requestor in the State of Washington. Respectfully we decline to use any 3rd party "portal" system, specifically GOVQA and NEXTREQUEST. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment, or via no password, no registration internet cloud-based download link.

Please do not direct or invite us to use, register for, or communicate with your agency via any 3rd party portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other commercial 3rd party records portal service.

 RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.
 
"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Unless the records exist IN PAPER FORM ONLY, DO NOT instead create new records by printing native stored electronic files, then scanning and re-printing these newly scanned prints only to reproduce them in again in electronic production.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION - FAMILY EDUCATIONAL RIGHTS AND PRIVACY ACT (FERPA)

Take caution with the broad application of redaction and withholding of identified public records claiming "global FERPA" exemptions. When an agency claims an exemption for an entire record or portion of one, it must inform the requestor of the statutory exemption and provide a brief explanation of how the exemption applies to the record or portion withheld. RCW 42.17.310(4)/42.56.210(3). The brief explanation should cite the statute the agency claims grant an exemption from disclosure. The brief explanation should provide enough information for a requestor to make a threshold determination of whether the claimed exemption is proper. Global, nonspecific claims of exemption such as "FERPA" are insufficient. One way to properly provide a brief explanation of the withheld record or redaction is for the agency to provide a withholding index. It identifies the type of record, its date and number of pages, and the author or recipient of the record (unless their identity is exempt). The withholding index should allow a requestor to make a threshold determination of whether the agency has properly invoked the exemption. There are several exceptions to the FERPA exemption and any agency silently withholding large swaths of public records citing "FERPA!" without providing the original identified record, properly redacted, or if withheld in its entirety, providing a record description and page count or record length, will be challenged in accordance with RCW 42.56.550 if a reasonably detailed withholding index or exemption log is not included.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

communications.subject: Re: Washington Public Records Act Request: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2021) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2021
communications.communication:
Good Day,

Shoreline School District confirms receipt of your request for public
records dated December 1, 2022, for a complete electronic copy of all
public records requests and responses for the year 2021.

Under Washington State RCW 42.56.520(2), the District is providing
notification that it will require additional time to locate and assemble
the records requested, review the records for possible exemptions, and/or
to provide notice to affected third parties.

We estimate that we will be responsive to your request on or before April
28, 2023.

The Shoreline School District policy 4040 and 4040p discusses various fees
related to the production of various paper and electronic records. There is
a 15 cents per copy fee for paper records, plus actual mailing charges, and
various costs for electronic records which may be efficiently reviewed
here:
http://web.shorelineschools.org/school_board/policy_manual/content/4040P.pdf on
pages 8 & 9, particularly. The District will assess the potentially
responsive records and provide an estimate to you prior to incurring any
charges. As noted in the referenced District procedure on page 9, we may
require a deposit prior to preparing the responsive records for release.

We will provide records earlier if possible or in installments as may be
feasible.
Best regards,

Jennifer

Jennifer A. Farmer
Assistant Superintendent Business & Operations
Shoreline School District

communications.subject: Re: Washington Public Records Act Request: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2021) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2021
communications.communication:
Good Day,

I am writing today to provide an update in our response date. Due to the
volume of records and significant staff shortages, we will extend our
anticipated response date to August 31, 2023. Installments may become
available during that time, and you will be updated with installments or
cost considerations as our work continues.
Best regards,

Jennifer
Shoreline School District
Public Records Office

Good Day.

I am writing to extend our anticipated response date to April 30, 2024, due to the volume of records and ongoing staff shortages. Installments may become available during that time, and you will be updated with installments or cost considerations as our work continues.

Regards.

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2021) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2021
communications.communication:
09-21-2024

via email to public.records@ssd412.org

No records have been produced. 

Provide a reasonable estimate of time to produce an installment of records.

WAC 44-06-085
Response to Public Records Act requests.

2(b) Reasonable estimate of time or costs. The office will provide an estimate of the time required to respond to the request, and may provide an estimate of copying costs pursuant to a specific request seeking an estimate of cost. If the requestor believes the amount of time or estimated costs stated are not reasonable, the requestor may petition the public records officer for a formal review under WAC 44-06-120.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC RECORDS *** ANTICIPATE LITIGATION ***


WAC 44-14-03005 RETENTION OF PUBLIC RECORDS

The lawful destruction of public records is governed by retention schedules. The unlawful destruction of public records can be a crime. RCW 40.16.010 and 40.16.020. An agency is prohibited from destroying a public record, even if it is about to be lawfully destroyed under a retention schedule, if a public records request has been made for that record. RCW 42.56.100. Additional retention requirements might apply if the records may be relevant to actual or anticipated litigation. The agency is required to retain the record until the record request has been resolved.

Note: An agency can be found to violate the Public Records Act and be subject to the attorneys' fees and penalty provision if it prematurely destroys a requested record after a request is made. See Yacobellis v. City of Bellingham, 55 Wn. App. 706, 780 P.2d 272 (1989). However, it is not a violation of the Public Records Act if a record is destroyed prior to an agency's receipt of a public records request for that record. Bldg. Indus. Ass'n of Wash. v. McCarthy, 152 Wn. App. 720, 218 P.3d 196 (2009); West v. Dep't of Nat. Res., 163 Wn. App. 238, 258 P.3d 78 (2011). The Public Records Act (chapter 42.56 RCW) and the records retention statutes (chapter 40.14 RCW) are two different laws.

communications.subject: 24-77 YEAR 2021 (1 of 3)
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

Due to the number of public records requests and the volume of records to
process, we have had delays in fulfilling your request for records.  We have
spent the time working on locating the relevant documents, scanning those
records that were only available as hard copies, redacting confidential
information, and calculating the associated costs.



Since your request has been delayed, we will not charge you for this
installment.  However, now that we can process requests more timely, we
will request payment for future installments.  The next installment should
be available on or before February 28, 2025.


The District has various fees for different types of records produced. You
may review our fee schedule beginning on page 8:
https://app.eduportal.com/documents/view/886377.

You will be notified when the next installment is available. If you have
not paid for and inspected the records within 30 days of the installment being
made available, the District reserves the right to close the request.


Please note the files are large, and this installment contains three emails.


Thank you for your patience and understanding as we work diligently to
complete your request.


Sincerely,


Public Records Department

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (January 2025) (Columbia County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Columbia County police disciplinary files
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- Any and all lists, spreadsheets or other organized datasets that detail potential or substantiated allegations of misconduct and/or impeached or impeachable testimony, created under Brady v. Maryland and/or Giglio v. United States.
- Any and all records regarding substantiated allegations of misconduct or violations of internal department policy or criminal law by specific law enforcement officers.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dillon Bergin

RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of 1/16/2025, Reference # W001349-011625 
Dear Dillon, 
The Columbia County Public Records Center received a public information request from you on 1/16/2025. Your request mentioned 
“To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

- Any and all lists, spreadsheets or other organized datasets that detail potential or substantiated allegations of misconduct and/or impeached or impeachable testimony, created under Brady v. Maryland and/or Giglio v. United States. 
- Any and all records regarding substantiated allegations of misconduct or violations of internal department policy or criminal law by specific law enforcement officers. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Dillon Bergin 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fcolumbia-county-prosecuting-attorney-35776%252Fcolumbia-county-police-disciplinary-files-179893%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAGwXiWKMmFXn_sLl68X4zPXfbI%3A1tYcIs%3ArL4QKCXOdbvXgcWdSI2HBpNk0gS4lVowBD7Jm38Wocc” 
The Columbia County Public Records Center has reviewed its files and has located responsive records to your request.  Please see the attached file. 
If you have any questions, or wish to discuss this further, please contact me. 
Sincerely, 
Virginia Schmidt 
Site Administrator
